(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1975
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
1
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"I have the honor to announce that the October 1975 Term of the
Supreme Court of the United States is now convened."
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 74-1324. Ronald Gendron, appellant, v. Edward H. Levi,
Attorney General of the United States, et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Central District of California. Judgment
affirmed.
No. 74-1465. Richard F. (Dick) Hayes, appellant, v. Florida et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Southern Dis-
trict of Florida. Judgment affirmed.
No. 74-1477. Fast Motor Service, Inc., appellant, v. United States
et al.; and
No. 74–1478. Fast Motor Service, Inc., appellant, v. United States
et al. Appeals from the United States District Court for the Northern
District of Illinois. Judgment affirmed.
No. 74–1553. W. D. Wilkey, appellant, v. Illinois Racing Board
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern
District of Illinois. Judgment affirmed.
No. 74-6410. Lea Spears, appellant, v. John E. Ellis, District
Attorney of Warren County, et al. Appeal fom the United States
District Court for the Southern District of Mississippi. Judgment
affirmed.
No. 74-6427. Minnie Lee Wilson, appellant, v. Gerald E. Malone
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Western
District of Kentucky. Judgment affirmed.
210-278-75-1

2
MONDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1975
No. 75-3. Jamaica Savings Bank, appellant, v. Louis J. Lefkowitz,
Attorney General of the State of New York. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Eastern District of New York. Judg-
ment affirmed.
No. 75-14. Louisville and Nashville Railroad Company, appellant,
v. Z. D. Atkins, Robert Clement and Cayce Pentecost, Commissioners,
Tennessee Public Service Commission, et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee. Judgment
affirmed.
No. 75-5006. Ira H. Kemp and Yrminda Fortes, appellants, v.
C. Delores Tucker, Secretary of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania,
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Middle
District of Pennsylvania. Judgment affirmed.
No. 74–1390. Town of Lockport, New York, et al., appellants, v.
Citizens for Community Action at the Local Level, Inc., et al. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the Western District of
New York. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States
District Court for the Western District of New York for reconsider-
ation in light of the provisions of the new charter adopted by Niagara
County in 1974.
No. 74-1475. Donald H. Stephens, appellant, v. L. D. Howle.
Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Georgia. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
Mr. Justice Douglas would note probable jurisdiction and set case for
oral argument.
No. 74-1497. William Scott and Ronald Kindred, appellants, v.
California. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, First
Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would note
-probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
No. 74-1501. Julian I. Richards, appellant, v. Barbara Jane
Richards et al. Appeal from the District of Columbia Court of
Appeals. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 74–1526. Margaret E. Thompson, appellant, v. County Board
of School Trustees of DuPage County, Illinois, et al. Appeal from
the Appellate Court of Illinois, Second District. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
i

MONDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1975
3
No. 74-1612. Herman Eger, appellant, v. Florida. Appeal from
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The appeal
is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon
the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari
denied.
No. 74-1631. Wyn Rummler, appellant, v. California. Appeal
from the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate District.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari denied.
No. 74-1636. Eric G. Mitchell, appellant, v. Mildred M. Mitchell.
Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, First Appellate
District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 74–6468. Ezra D. Anderson, Jr., et al., appellants, v. United
States District Court for the District of Massachusetts. Appeal from
the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 74-6661. Sylvia Cisneros, appellant, v. The Orange County
Superior Court, Sitting as the Juvenile Court. Appeal from the Court
of Appeal of California, Fourth Appellate District. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 74-6719. Noel Tancred Escofil, appellant, v. Commissioner of
Internal Revenue. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals
for the Third Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-
tion. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 74-6723. William Richardson, appellant, v. Illinois. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as
a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 74-1515. Henry E. Howell, Jr., appellant, v. The Chesapeake
and Potomac Telephone Company of Virginia et al. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Virginia. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this appeal.
No. 74-1521. Covington Fabrics Corp., appellant, v. South Caro-
lina Tax Commission. Appeal from the Supreme Court of South Caro-
lina. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.

4
MONDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1975
No. 74-1541. Bernard Weinstock et al., appellant, v. Town of Hull
et al. Appeal from the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachuseets. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 74–1570, Calvin Williams and Joseph McNeil, appellants, v.
Pennsylvania Department of Labor and Industry and Department of
Health. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Eastern
District. The appeal is dimissed for want of a substantial federal.
question.
No. 74–1578. Town of Manchester, Connecticut, appellant, v. Mu-
riel P. Grover. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Connecticut. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 74-1581. Baltimore & Ohio Railroad Co., et al., appellants, v.
Pennsylvania Department of Labor and Industry et al. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Western District. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 74–1582. Sherry White, appellant, v. Kenneth O. Hughes.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Arkansas. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 74-1585. B. Coleman Corporation, appellant, v. 47th and State
Currency Exchange, Inc. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Illinois.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 74–1609. Robbins Men's & Boys' Wear Corp., appellant, v.
City of New York. Appeal from the Appellate Division of the
Supreme Court of New York, Second Judicial Department. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 74-1614. Wilbert Lee Ballard, appellant, v. Board of Trustees
of the Police Pension Fund of the City of Evansville, Indiana. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Indiana. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question.
No. 74-6398. Edward Marion Cialkowski, appellant, v. Nebraska.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Nebraska. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 74–6666. Ralph Wade et ux., appellants, v. Oregon ex rel.
Juvenile Department of Multnomah County. Appeal from the Court
of Appeals of Oregon. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question.
No. 75-34. Colin F. Beaton et ux., appellants, v. Judges of the
Land Court et al. Appeal from the Supreme Judicial Court of Massa-
chusetts. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1975
5
No. 75-115. Jerry DiDonato, appellant, v. Charles Feldman and
William Feldman. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California,
Second Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question.
No. 75-140. Reithoffer's, Inc., appellant, v. Board of Supervisors
of Fairfax County, Virginia. Appeal from the Circuit Court of Vir-
ginia, Fairfax County. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question.
No. 74-1565. Seacoast Transportation Company, appellant, v. An-
tonio Perez et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Florida. Motion
of appellee Perez for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari denied. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration
or decision of this motion and appeal.
No. 74-1628. John A. Hutter, appellant, v. Bernard Korzen etc.
Appeal from the Appellate Court of Illinois, First District. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction, it appearing that there is
no final judgment of the highest court of a State wherein a judgment
could be had as required by 28 U.S.C. § 1257.
No. 74-6441. Anthony Gardiner Lowell, appellant, v. Elsa Aman,
etc. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, First Appellate
District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question. Mr. Justice Douglas would note probable jurisdiction and
set case for oral argument.
No. 75-26. Fred Carroll Lucas and Ronnie Ray Lucas, appellants,
v. Arkansas. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Arkansas. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice
Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall would note probable jurisdiction
and set case for oral argument.
No. 75-28. Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel, Inc., et al., appellants,
v. United States et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the District of Columbia. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Powell
took no part in the consideration or decision of this appeal.
No. 75-38. Township of Mount Laurel, appellant, v. Southern Bur-
lington County N.A.A.C.P. et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
New Jersey. Motion of appellees Clark et al. for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis granted. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-
tion. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied. Mr. Justice Marshall took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion and appeal.

6
MONDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1975
No. 75-81. Romae Powell, Individually and as Judge of the Juve-
nile Court of Fulton County et al., appellants, v. Richard Wayne Long,
etc. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern
District of Georgia. Motion of appellee for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the Northern District of Georgia with direc-
tions to dismiss the case as moot. Mr. Justice Douglas would affirm
judgment below.
No. 75-142. F. David Mathews, Secretary of Health, Education
and Welfare, appellant, v. Jesus Rodriguez Cintron. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the District of Puerto Rico. Judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the United States District Court
for the District of Puerto Rico for consideration of the question of
mootness; if the cause is not moot, for reconsideration of the deter-
mination of class action in light of Weinberger v. Salfi, 422 U.S.—
(1975).
No. 75-5033. Clarence M. Davis, appellant, v. Charles Morris,
Secretary of the Department of Social and Health Service of Wash-
ington. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Washington. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice
Douglas and Mr. Justice Brennan would note probable jurisdiction
and set case for oral argument.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 74–1372. Anthony P. Travisono et al., petitioners, v. Anthony
Souza et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. Motion of respondent Souza
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certio-
rari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further consideration in light of Alyeska Pipeline Serv-
ice Co. v. Wilderness Society, 421 U.S. 240 (1975).
No. 74-1413. William T. Coleman, Jr., Secretary of Transporta-
tion, et al., petitioners, v. The Conservation Society of Southern Ver-
mont, Inc., et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Petition for writ of certio-
rari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further consideration in light of Pub. L. 94-83 and Aber-
deen & Rockfish R.R. Co. v. SCRAP, 422 U.S.———— (1975).
No. 74-1446. Henry Lee Rogers et al., petitioners, v. International
Paper Company et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Petition for writ of

MONDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1975
7
certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further consideration in light of Albemarle Paper Co.
v. Moody, 422 U.S. (1975).
No. 74-1470. Louisiana, petitioner, v. William August Mora, Jr.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Louisiana.
Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and peti-
tion for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case re-
manded to the Supreme Court of Louisiana to consider whether its
judgment is based upon federal or state constitutional grounds, or
both. See California v. Krivda, 409 U.S. 33 (1972).
No. 75-46. Roundhouse Construction Corporation, petitioner, v.
Telesco Masons Supplies Co. et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to
the Supreme Court of Connecticut. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the Supreme Court
of Connecticut to consider whether its judgment is based upon federal
or state constitutional grounds, or both. See California v. Krivda, 409
U.S. 33 (1972).
No. 75-83. The University of Chicago and Argonne, petitioners, v.
Louis Allen McDaniel, Jr. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Petition for
writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further consideration in light of Securities In-
vestor Protection Corp. v. Barbour, 421 U.S. 412 (1975) and Cort v.
Ash, 422 U.S. 66 (1975).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-187. Federal Power Commission, applicant, v. Transcon-
tinental Gas Pipeline Corporation. The application for stay of the
mandate of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of
Columbia Circuit, presented to the Chief Justice and by him referred
to the Court, is granted pending the timely filing of a petition for a
writ of certiorari and final disposition thereon. Mr. Justice Powell
took no part in the consideration or decision of this application.
No. A-218. Theodore W. Bettker, applicant, v. United States Dis-
trict Court for the Southern District of Ohio. The application for stay
of the order of the United States District Court for the Southern
District of Ohio dated December 16, 1974, presented to Mr. Justice
Stewart and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. A-230. C. Arnholt Smith et al., applicants, v. United States
and County of San Diego, California. The motion of the County of

کا باری است
6, 1975
Swith whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins
San Diego to vacate the stay heretofore granted by Mr. Justice Doug-
las on September 11, 1975, is granted. Mr. Justice Douglas dissents for
the reasons stated in his opinion of September 11, 1975, 423 U.S.
in which he granted a stay of the District Court's order.
No. D-49. In the Matter of Disbarment of Loren Grant Ishler. Dis-
barment entered.
No. D-50. In the Matter of Disbarment of Franklin D. Rubin. It is
ordered that Franklin D. Rubin, of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-51. In the Matter of Disbarment of Halbert E. Whitaker.
It is ordered that Halbert E. Whitaker, of Cleveland, Ohio, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-52. In the Matter of Disbarment of Gerald L. Shaffer. It is
ordered that Gerald L. Shaffer, of Fort Dodge, Iowa, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-53. In the Matter of Disbarment of Roy Aaron Golden. It is
ordered that Roy Aaron Golden, of Des Moines, Iowa, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-54. In the Matter of Disbarment of Jerome B. Wolff. It is
ordered that Jerome B. Wolff, of Stevenson, Maryland, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-55. In the Matter of Disbarment of Ronald Robert Silver-
ton. It is ordered that Ronald Robert Silverton, of Los Angeles, Cali-
fornia, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that
a rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show
cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this
Court.
No. D-56. In the Matter of Disbarment of James George Demo-
poulos. It is ordered that James George Demopoulos, of Chicago,
Illinois, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that
a rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

No. 35, Original. United States of America, plaintiff v. State of
Maine et al. The joint motion for entry of a decree is granted. Decree
entered.
No. 67, Original. State of Idaho ex rel. Cecil D. Andrus, Governor,
Wayne L. Kidwell, Attorney General, Joseph C. Greenley, Director,
Department of Fish and Game, plaintiff v. States of Oregon and
Washington;
No. 74-1623. Chester Slone et al., appellants, v. Deskins Branch
Coal Company et al.; and
No. 75-93. Town of Sorrento Municipal Democratic Executive
Committee et al., appellants, v. Glynn Reine et al. The Solicitor Gen-
eral is invited to file briefs in these cases expressing the views of the
United States.
No. 73–1288. Alfred Dunhill of London, Inc., petitioner, v. The
Republic of Cuba et al. The motion of respondents for additional time
for oral argument is granted and fifteen additional minutes are al-
loted for that purpose. The petitioner is also allotted fifteen additional
minutes for oral argument.
No. 73–1908. Stewart S. Cort et al., petitioners, v. Richard A.
Ash, etc. The motion of respondent Ash to have Bethlehem Steel Cor-
poration bear costs is denied.
No. 73-6935. Marcel Youakim et al., appellants, v. Jerome Miller,
Individually and as Director of the Department of Children and
Family Services, et al. The motion of the Youth Law Center for leave
to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is denied.
No. 74–362. Intercounty Construction Corporation et al., petition-
ers, v. Noah C. A. Walter, etc, et al. The motion of respondents Jones
et al. to tax costs is denied.
No. 74-450. Administrator, Federal Aviation Administration, et
al., petitioners, v. Reuben B. Robertson, III, et al. The motion of
respondents to retax costs is granted.
No. 74-466. John T. Dunlop, Secretary of Labor, petitioner, v.
Walter Bachowski. The motion of respondent to retax costs is denied.
No. 74-611. United States et al., petitioners, v. C. D. Kasmir and
Jerry A. Candy. The motion of respondents for additional time for
oral argument is denied. The motion of National Society of Public
Accountants for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 74-728. Harold Franks and Johnnie Lee, petitioners, v. Bow-
man Transportation Company, Inc., et al. Consideration of the sug-

10
MONDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1975
gestion of mootness is deferred to the hearing of the case on the merits.
The motion of Local 862, United Automobile Workers, for leave to
file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted. The motion of Local 862,
United Automobile Workers for leave to participate in oral argument,
as amicus curiae, is denied.
No. 74-742. Foremost-McKesson, Inc., petitioner, v. Provident
Securities Company. The motion of Gulf & Western Industries, Inc.,
for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 74-799. United States, petitioner, v. Foster Lumber Company,
Inc. The motion of Data Products Corporation for leave to participate
in oral argument, as amicus curiae, is denied.
No. 74-858. Hugh L. Carey, Governor of the State of New York,
et al., appellants, v. Bert Randolph Sugar and Wrestling Revue, Inc.;
and
No. 74-859. Curtis Circulation Company and Continental Casu-
alty Company appellants, v. Bert Randolph Sugar and Wrestling
Revue, Inc. The motion of The Legal Aid Society of New York City
for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 74-883. Federal Power Commission, petitioner, v. John E.
Moss et al. The motion to dispense with printing the appendix and
to proceed on the original record is granted. Mr. Justice Stewart and
Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion.
No. 74-884. United States, petitioner, v. Josephine M. Powell. The
motion of the Solicitor General to permit Frank H. Easterbrook to
present oral argument, pro hac vice, is granted.
No. 74-895. Virginia State Board of Pharmacy et al., appellants,
v. Virginia Citizens Consumer Council, Inc., et al. The motion of the
American Association of Retired Persons et al. for leave to file a brief,
as amici curiae, is granted.
No. 74-1015. Intercounty Construction Corporation et al., petition-
ers, v. Noah C. A. Walter, etc., et al. The motion of respondent Jones
to tax attorney's fees and costs is denied.
No. 74-1023. Henry W. Kerr et al., petitioners, v. United States
District Court for the Northern District of California et al. Considera-
tion of respondents' suggestion of mootness is deferred to the hearing
of the case on the merits.
No. 74-1025. Burtice A. Hines et al., petitioners, v. Anchor Motor
Freight, Inc., et al. The motion to substitute Charles A. Hines as a
etc.
party petitioner in place of Burtice A. Hines, deceased, is granted.

The motion of Prod, Inc., et al., for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae,
is granted. The motion of American Federation of Labor and Con-
gress of Industrial Organizations for leave to file a brief, as amicus

No. 74-1033. C. Marshall Dann, Commissioner of Patents and
Trademarks, petitioner, v. Thomas R. Johnston. The motion of Com-
puter and Business Equipment Manufacturers Association for leave
to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 74–1042. Ernst & Ernst, petitioner, v. Olga Hochfelder et al.
The motion of the Solicitor General to permit the Securities and Ex-
change Commission to participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae,
is granted and fifteen additional minutes are allotted for that purpose.
The motion of American Institute of Certified Public Accountants for
leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 74-1044. Massachusetts Board of Retirement et al., appellants,
v. Robert D. Murgia. The motion of American Medical Association for
leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 74–1055. W. T. Stone, Warden, petitioner, v. Lloyd Charles
Powell. The motion for appointment of counsel is granted and Robert
W. Peterson, Esquire, of Santa Clara, California, is appointed to
serve as counsel for respondent in this case.
No. 74–1137. Abe Lavine, etc., appellant, v. Ronald Milne et al.
The motion to permit Gerald A. Norlander, Esquire, to present oral
argument, pro hac vice, on behalf of the appelles is granted.
No. 74–1222. Charles L. Wolff, Jr., Warden, petitioner, v. David
L. Rice. The motion of Americans for Effective Law Enforcement,
Inc., et al., for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, is granted.
No. 74–1245. Liberty Mutual Insurance Company, petitioner, v.
Sandra Wetzel et al. The motion of Alaska Airlines, Inc., et al., for
leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, is granted. The motion of the
Chamber of Commerce of the United States for leave to file a brief,
as amicus curiae, is denied.
No. 74-1269. Eugene R. Kelley, Commissioner of the Suffolk
County Police Department, petitioner, v. Thomas Dwen, etc. The
motion of the International Brotherhood of Police Officers for leave to
file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 74-1274. Abbott Laboratories et al., petitioners, v. Portland
Retail Druggists Association, Inc., etc. The motion of American
Hospital Association for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is
granted.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1975
No. 74-5435. Paul Kern Imbler, petitioner, v. Richard Pachtman.
The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral
argument, as amicus curiae, is granted and fifteen additional minutes
are allotted for that purpose. The motion of the Attorney General of
California to participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, is denied.
No. 74-6293. Philip J. Goldberg, petitioner, v. United States. The
motion of petitioner for appointment of counsel is granted and Donald
C. Smaltz, Esquire, of Los Angeles, California, is appointed to serve
as counsel for the petitioner in this case. The motion of California
Attorneys for Criminal Justice et al., for leave to participate in oral
argument, as amici curiae, is denied.
No. 75-323. In the Matter of the Witness Charles G. Berry, peti-
tioner. The application for stay of confinement pending action on the
petition for writ of certiorari, presented to Mr. Justice Douglas and
by him referred to the Court, is denied.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 74-1481. American Motorists Insurance Company, appellant, v.
Virgil B. Starnes. Appeal from the Court of Civil Appeals of Texas,
Tenth Supreme Judicial District. In this case probable jurisdiction
noted.
No. 74-1488. Secretary of the Interior, appellant, v. New Mexico
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District
of New Mexico. In this case probable jurisdiction noted.
No. 74–1607. Harry R. Hughes, etc., et al., appellants, v. Alexan-
dria Scrap Corporation. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the District of Maryland. In this case probable jurisdiction noted.
No. 74-1151. Planned Parenthood of Central Missouri et al., ap-
pellants, v. John C. Danforth, Attorney General of the State of Mis-
souri, et al.; and
No. 74-1419. John C. Danforth, Attorney General of the State of
Missouri, appellant, v. Planned Parenthood of Central Missouri et al.
Appeals from the United States District Court for the Eastern Dis-
trict of Missouri. In this case probable jurisdiction noted. Cases con-
solidated and a total of one hour allotted for oral argument.
No. 74-1656. John C. Moe, etc., et al., appellants, v. The Confed-
erated Salish and Kootenai Tribes of the Flathead Reservation et al.;
and
No. 75-50. The Confederated Salish and Kootenai Tribes of the
Flathead Reservation et al., appellants, v. John C. Moe, etc., et al.
Appeals from the United States District Court for the District of

MONDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1975
13
Montana. In these cases probable jurisdiction noted. Cases consolidate
and a total of one hour allotted for oral argument.
No. 75–88. F. David Mathews, Secretary of Health, Education and
Welfare, appellant, v. Ruby M. Lucas et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the District of Rhode Island. Motion of
appellees for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. In this case
probable jurisdiction noted and case set for oral argument in tandem
with No. 74–6212, Norton v. Mathews.
No. 75-436. James L. Buckley et al., appellants, v. Francis R. Valeo,
Secretary of the United States Senate, et al. Appeal from the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit; and
No. 75-437. James L. Buckley et al., appellants, v. Francis R.
Valeo, Secretary of the United States Senate, et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the District of Columbia.
In these cases probable jurisdiction noted. Cases consolidated and a
total of four hours allotted for oral argument to be evenly divided.
between the appellants and the appellees. Motion of Senators Hugh
Scott and Edward M. Kennedy for leave to permit oral argument on
their behalf, as amici curiae, denied without prejudice to their seek-
ing part of the two hours allotted the appellees.
CERTIORARI GRANTED

writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Wisconsin granted.

Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit granted.
No. 75-122. Lawrence Cantor dba Selden Drugs Company, etc.,
petitioner, v. The Detroit Edison Company. Petition for writ of cer-

granted.
No. 75-246. United States, petitioner, v. Roy C. Hopkins. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Claims granted.
No. 74-1487. United States, petitioner, v. Colin F. MacCollom.
Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit granted. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the
consideration or decision of this motion and petition.
No. 74-1529. Robert J. Henderson, Superintendent, Auburn Cor-
rectional Facility, petitioner, v. Timothy G. Morgan. Motion of re-
spondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit granted.
No. 74-1542. Union Electric Company, petitioner, v. Environ-
mental Protection Agency. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit granted limited to
Question 1 presented by the petition which reads as follows:
"1. Does the Section of the Clean Air Act (Section 307 (b)(1)),
which provides for judicial review by the Court of Appeals of EPA
approval of sulfur dioxide emission regulations in the Missouri imple-
mentation plan, prevent the Court of Appeals from considering tech-
nological and economic factors applicable to petitioner and such regu-
lations, when the petition for judicial review was filed more than 30
days after EPA approval of such plan, when such technological and
economic factors arose more than 30 days after EPA approval and
when those factors make it impossible for petitioner to comply with
those regulations and manifestly against the public interest for it to
attempt to do so?"

MONDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1975
15
No. 74–1560. United States, petitioner, v. Amado Martinez-Fuerte
et al. Motion of respondents for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit granted. Motion to strike portions of peti-
tion denied.
No. 74-1589. General Electric Company, petitioner, v. Martha V.
Gilbert et al.; and
No. 74-1590. Martha V. Gilbert et al., petitioners, v. General Elec-
tric Company. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit granted. Cases consolidated
and a total of one hour allotted for oral argument.
No. 74-1646. Peter C. Andresen, petitioner, v. Maryland. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Court of Special Appeals of Maryland
granted limited to Questions I and II presented by the petition which
read as follows:
"I. May an attorney at law, who is a sole practitioner, invoke his
previlege against self-incrimination under Amendment V to the Con-
stitution of the United States, to prevent the introduction of his per-
sonal handwritten notes and memoranda, books and records, which
were seized from his desk and files in his personal office, under a search
warrant held to be otherwise reasonable, into evidence against him at
his criminal trial?
"II. Was the search of petitioner's offices violative of Amendment
IV to the Constitution of the United States?"
No. 74–6521. Monica Aldinger, petitioner, v. Merton L. Howard,
etc., et al. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit granted.
No. 75-5014. Jefferson Doyle, petitioner, v. Ohio; and
No. 75-5015. Richard Wood, petitioner, v. Ohio. Motions of
petitioners for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petitions
for writs of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tuscarawas
County, granted limited to Questions 1 and 2 presented by the peti-
tions which read as follows:
"1. Whether an accused who asserts his right of silence and his
right to counsel following his arrest properly subjects himself:
(a) to questions as to why he did not protest his innocence at
the point of arrest, at the Preliminary Hearing, or at some time
earlier than at the trial;

16
MONDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1975
(6) to the prosecutor's argument to the jury that an unfavor-
able inference could be drawn against the accused as a conse-
quence of his having exercised these constitutional rights;
(c) to questions as to why he did not consent to the search of
the car (thus necessitating obtaining a search warrant) and to an
argument on this point.
"2. Whether a defense witness who was arrested and charged along
with the defendant on trial can be properly asked why he did not pro-
test his innocence earlier than at the trial, and can the prosecutor
argue this point to the jury?”
Cases consolidated and a total of one hour allotted for oral
argument.
CERTIORARI DENIED

ADMISSIONS OF ATTORNEYS DURING THE SUMMER RECESS
The following attorneys were admitted to the Bar of this Court by
actions of single Justices during the summer recess, pursuant to the
Order of this Court entered on the twenty-fourth day of May, 1971:

ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 73-2066. National Independent Coal Operator's Association
et al., petitioners, v. Secretary of the Interior et al.; and
No. 74-521. Secretary of the Interior, petitioner, v. Delta Mining,
Inc., et al. Argued by Mr. John L. Kilcullen for the National Inde-
pendent Coal Operator's Association et al., by Mr. Fred Blackwell for
Delta Mining, Inc., et al., and by Mr. A. Raymond Randolph, Jr., for
the Secretary of the Interior et al.
No. 74–204. F. David Mathews, Secretary of Health, Education,
and Welfare, petitioner, v. George H. Eldridge. Argued by Mr. So-
licitor General Bork for the petitioner and by Mr. Donald E. Earls
for the respondent. Memorandum to come.
No. 74-653. Michigan, petitioner, v. Richard Bert Mosley. Argued
by Mr. Thomas Khalil for the petitioner and by Mr. Carl Ziemba
for the respondent.
No. 74-884. United States, petitioner, v. Josephine M. Powell.
Argued by Mr. Frank H. Easterbrook for the petitioner, pro hac vice,
by special leave of Court, and by Mr. Jerry J. Moberg for the respond-
ent, pro hac vice, by special leave of Court.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 74-1427. Reuben L. Anderson-Cherne, Inc., appellant, v. The
Commissioner of Revenue of the State of Minnesota. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Minnesota. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 75-178. Martin E. Ganschow, appellant, v. Marie D. Ganschow.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of California. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 75-5266. Joseph C. Pauley, appellant, v. Massachusetts.
Appeal from the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 75–186. Sherman M. Godsy, Jr., appellant, v. Nadine Godsy.
Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Missouri, Kansas City District.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari denied.
No. 75–262. Henry Dodge et al., appellants, v. Richard H. Austin,
etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the East-
ern District of Michigan. Judgment affirmed.
No. 75–5349. Samuel Corrado et ux., appellants, v. City of Provi-
dence et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Rhode Island. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
William L. Calley, Jr., applicant, v. Howard H.
Callaway, Secretary of the Army, et al. The motion to dispense with
printing portions of the appendix to the petition for writ of certiorari
is granted. The typewritten or otherwise reproduced copies of the
non-printed opinions will be accepted only if legible.
No. D-57. In the Matter of Disbarment of Russell Edward Parsons.
It is ordered that Russell Edward Parsons, of Santa Ana, Cali-
210-278-75-9

110
TUESDAY, OCTOBER 14, 1975
fornia, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that
a rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-58. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert Earl Tarbox.
It is ordered that Robert Earl Tarbox, of San Francisco, California, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-59. In the Matter of Disbarment of Raymond Alexander
Nelson. It is ordered that Raymond Alexander Nelson, of San An-
selmo, California, be suspended from the practice of law in this
Court and that a rule issued, returnable within forty days, requiring
him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice
of law in this Court.
No. 74-175. J. William Middendorf, II, et al., petitioners, v. Daniel
Edward Henry et al.; and
No. 74–5176. Daniel Edward Henry et al., petitioners, v. J. Wil-
liam Middendorf, II, individually and his capacity as Secretary of the
Navy, et al. The motion for leave to file memorandum suggesting that
this Court's holdings, after oral argument, in these cases at bar raise
new questions of law is granted.
No. 74-851. Lynn Seeber, General Manager of the Tennessee
Valley Authority, et al., petitioners, v. Alabama et al. The motion of
the respondents to consolidate this case with No. 74-220, Hancock v.
Train et al. is denied.
No. 74-1222. Charles L. Wolff, Jr., Warden, petitioner, v. David L.
Rice. The motion of the respondent for the appointment of counsel
is granted and J. Patrick Green, Esquire, of Omaha, Nebraska, is
appointed to serve as counsel for the respondent in this case.
No. 74-1270. Russell Train, Administrator of the Environmental
Protection Agency, et al., petitioners, v. Colorado Public Interest Re-
search Group, Inc. et al. The motion of Michael S. Baram et al., for
leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, is granted.
No. 74-1274. Abbott Laboratories et al., petitioners, v. Portland
Retail Druggists Association, Inc., etc. The motion of Alabama Phar-
maceutical Association et al., for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, is
granted.
No. 74-1396. Michelin Tire Corporation, petitioner, v. W. L.
Wages, Tax Commissioner, et al. The motion of Los Angeles County
et al. for leave to participate in oral argument, as amici curiae, is
denied.
1

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 14, 1975
111
No. 75-409. Frederick Finkbeiner, petitioner, v. Richard Mattox.
The application for a stay of the mandate of the United States Court
of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, presented to Mr. Justice Rehn-
quist, and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. 75-436. James L. Buckley et al., appellants, v. Francis R. Valeo,
Secretary of the United States Senate, et al.; and
No. 75-437. James L. Buckley et al., appellants, v. Francis R. Valeo,
Secretary of the United States Senate, et al. The motion of Brice M.
Glaggett, Esquire, to permit Ralph K. Winter, Jr., Esquire, to present
oral argument, pro hac vice, is granted. The motion of Senator Lee
Metcalf for leave to permit oral argument on his behalf, as amicus
curiae, is denied without prejudice to his seeking part of the four hours
allotted the litigants in these cases.
No. 75-471. John W. Collis, petitioner, v. Kentucky Bar Associa-
tion. The motion to vacate the stay herefore granted by Mr. Justice
Stewart on September 25, 1975, is denied.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 74-1303. Carl D. Bishop, petitioner, v. W. H. Wood, etc.,
et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit granted.
No. 74-1563. City of Eastlake, et al., petitioners, v. Forest City
Enterprises, Inc. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court
of Ohio granted.
No. 75-19. United States, petitioner, v. Dominga Santana and
William Alejandro. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit granted.
No. 75-110. Bernard A. Sakraida, petitioner, v. Ag Pro, Inc.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit granted.
No. 75-185. Lodge 76, International Association of Machinists and
Aerospace Workers, AFL-CIO, et al., petitioners, v. Wisconsin Em-
ployment Relations Commission et al. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the Supreme Court of Wisconsin granted.
No. 75-250. City of Charlotte et al., petitioners, v. Local 660,
International Association of Firefighters, et al. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Cir-
cuit granted.
No. 74-1608. National Association for the Advancement of Colored
People et al., petitioners, v. Federal Power Commission; and

112
TUESDAY, OCTOBER 14, 1975
No. 74–1619. Federal Power Commission, petitioner, v. National
Association for the Advancement of Colored People et al. Petitions for
writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Dis-
trict of Columbia Circuit granted. Cases consolidated and a total of
one hour allocated for oral argument. Mr. Justice Marshall took no
part in the consideration or decision of these cases.
No. 75-145. The Northern Cheyenne Tribe, petitioner, v. William
Hollowbreast et al. Motions of respondents for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted.
No. 75–130. Robert J. Quinn, Individually and as Commissioner of
the Chicago Fire Department, petitioner, v. Tom C. Clark et al. Motion
for leave to file petition for writ of mandamus denied. The alternative
petition for writ of certiorari to review the judgment of the United
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit (No. 74-1460) is
granted. The case is recaptioned in this Court as Robert J. Quinn, In-
dividually and as Commissioner, Chicago Fire Department, petitioner,
v. Francis Muscare, to reflect the true respondent in this case.

LEAVE TO FILE PETITIONS FOR WRITS OF HABEAS CORPUS DENIED
No. 75-522. Fred C. Tallant, Sr., and William M. Womack, Jr.,
petitioners, v James H. Henson, United States Marshal, etc., et al.;
and
No. 75-5280. Michael Dunn, petitioner, v. California. Motions for
leave to file petitions for writs of habeas corpus denied.
ASSIGNMENT ORDERS
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for the purpose of hearing the appeal
in the case of USA v. Carden, No. 74-3037, and for such additional
time as may be required to complete unfinished business, pursuant to
28 U.S.C. § 294 (a) is ordered entered on the minutes of this Court,
pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit during the week of November 10,
1975, and for such additional time as may be required to complete un-
finished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a) is ordered entered on
the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit from December 11,
1975, to December 17, 1975, and for such additional time as may be
required to complete unfinished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C.
§ 294 (a) is ordered entered on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to
28 U.S.C. § 295.
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Appeals for the Third Circuit on April 8 and 9, 1976, and for such
additional time as may be required to complete unfinished business,
pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a) is ordered entered on the minutes of
this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 14, 1975
RECESS ORDER
121
The Court will take a recess from Monday, October 20, 1975, until
Monday, November 3, 1975.

210-278-75-11



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, OCTOBER 20, 1975
135
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall,
Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 74-6715. Bruce Kline and John Young, appellants, v. Illinois.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied. Mr. Justice
Brennan would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral
argument.
No. 75–207. Appalachian Power Company, appellant, v. The Public
Service Commission of West Virginia. Appeal from the Supreme Court
of Appeals of West Virginia. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the
consideration or decision of this appeal.
No. 75–263. Board of Education of Armstrong High School Dis-
trict No. 225, etc., et al., appellants, v. James H. Ellis, etc., et al. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question.
No. 75–295. Albert Simon, Inc., et al., appellants, v. Bess Myerson,
etc. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 75–305. Griggs, Cooper & Co., Inc., appellant, v. Joseph Novak,
etc., et al.; and
No. 75-315. Heaven Hill Distilleries, Inc., appellant, v. Joseph
Novak, etc., et al. Appeals from the Supreme Court of Minnesota. The
appeals are dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 75-5081. Katie Mae Howlett, appellant, v. Federal National
Mortgage Association. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Missouri.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
210-278-75– -12

136
MONDAY, OCTOBER 20, 1975
No. 75-5314. Beve P. Smith, appellant, v. Kentucky. Appeal from
the Court of Appeals of Kentucky. The appeal is dismissed for want of
a substantial federal question.
No. 75–279. Virginia Baker and Russell Carl Baker, appellants, v.
W. C. Owen, etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Middle District of North Carolina. Judgment affirmed.
No. 75-284. Metropolitan Dade County, Florida, et al., appellants,
v. Aerojet-General Corporation. Appeal from the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 9, Original. United States of America, plaintiff, v. State of
Louisiana et al. The First Accounting of Louisiana filed pursuant to
the Decree of June 16, 1975; the Accounting by the United States
filed pursuant to paragraph 6(b) of the Decree of June 16, 1975; the
Accounting by Louisiana filed pursuant to paragraph 5 of the Decree
of June 16, 1975; and the Accounting by the United States filed pur-
suant to paragraphs 5(b) and 7 of the Decree of June 16, 1975, are
referred to the Special Master.
No. 36, Original. State of Texas, plaintiff, v. State of Louisiana.
The exceptions to the Report of the Special Master are set for oral
argument in due course.
No. A-151. Jill Raymond, applicant, v. United States. The appli-
cation for stay of execution of judgment and/or bail pending appeal,
presented to Mr. Justice Stewart and by him referred to the Court, is
denied.
No. 74-882. Leonor Alberti DeCanas and Miguel Canas, petitioners,
v. Anthony G. Bica and Juan Silva. The motion of petitioners for
divided argument is denied.
No. 74–1107. Francis Leo Cappaert et al., petitioners, v. United
States et al.; and
No. 74-1304. Nevada ex rel. Roland D. Westergard, State Engineer,
petitioner, v. United States et al. The motion of petitioners for addi-
tional time for oral argument is granted and fifteen additional min-
utes are allotted for that purpose. The respondents are allotted fifteen
additional minutes for oral argument.
No. 74–1245. Liberty Mutual Insurance Company, petitioner, v.
Sandra Wetzel et al. The motion of the Attorney General of Ohio for
leave to participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, is denied.

No. 75-82. Sheet Metal Workers' International Association, peti-

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 3, 1975
153
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 75-245. Day and Zimmermann, Inc., petitioner, v. Hawley K.
Challoner et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Petition for writ of certio-
rari granted, judgment vacated, and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion per curiam. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 75-134. Mary Young Cannon, appellant, v. William J. Guste,
Jr., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the East-
ern District of Louisiana. Judgment affirmed.
No. 75-257. Leslie H. Baker, Jr., appellant, v. United States. Ap-
peal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari denied.
No. 75-302. Len H. Small et al., appellants, v. Charles L. Pangle,
etc., et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 75-5342. George C. Matthews, appellant, v. Michael N. Ka-
vouklis, etc., et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 75–333. Kenneth E. North, appellant, v. Patricia Anne North.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Kansas. Motion of appellee for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
210-278-75-14

154
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 3, 1975
No. 75-372. Brian O'Donnell et al., appellants, v. Arthur A. Antin
et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 75-5252. Edwin B. Lee and Rita M. Lee et al., appellants, v.
Child Care Service Delaware County Institution District et al. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Eastern District. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 75-5169. Edwin R. Breaux, petitioner, v. United States; and
No. 75-5223. George Evans Harp, petitioner, v. United States. On
petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. Motions for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and petitions for writs of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and
cases remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in
light of United States v. Hale, U.S./7/ (1975).
422
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 64, Original. State of New Hampshire, plaintiff, v. State of
Maine. The Report of the Special Master is received and ordered filed.
Exceptions, if any, may be filed by the parties within 45 days. Reply
briefs, if any, may be filed within 30 days thereafter.
No. A-318. Vincenzo Burrafato et ux., applicants, v. United States
Department of State et al. The application for stay of the mandate
of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit and/or
stay of deportation, presented to Mr. Justice Douglas and by him
referred to the Court, is denied.
No. A-323. Internal Revenue Service, applicant, v. Fruehauf Cor-
poration et al. The motion to vacate the stay heretofore granted by
Mr. Justice Stewart on October 9, 1975, is denied.
No. D-47. In Matter of Disbarment of Ronald W. Mayes. Disbar-
ment entered.
No. 73-861. East Carroll Parish School Board and East Carroll
Parish Police Jury, petitioners, v. Stewart Marshall. The motion of
the Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights Under Law for leave to file
a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 73–1596. Robert E. Hampton, Chairman of the United States
Civil Service Commission, et al., petitioners, v. Mow Sun Wong et al.
The motion for appointment of counsel is granted and Edward H.
Steinman, Esquire, of Santa Clara, California, is appointed to serve
as counsel for the respondents in this case.

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 3, 1975
155
No. 74-175. J. William Middendorf, II, et al., petitioners, v. Daniel
Edward Henry et al.; and
No. 74–5176. Daniel Edward Henry et al., petitioners, v. J. William
Middendorf, II, individually and in his capacity as Secretary of the
Navy, et al. The motion of the Solicitor General to permit Harvey M.
Stone, Esquire, to present oral argument, pro hac vice, is granted.
No. 74–1222. Charles L. Wolff, Jr., Warden, petitioner, v. David
L. Rice. The motion of the Atorney General of New Jersey for leave
to participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, is denied.
No. 74-1304. Nevada ex rel. Roland D. Westergard, State Engi-
neer, petitioner, v. United States et al. The motion of the Salt River
Pima-Maricopa Indian Community et al., for leave to file a brief, as
amici curiae, is granted.
No. 74–1560. United States, petitioner, v. Amado Martinez-Fuerte
et al. The motion for appointment of counsel is granted and Charles M.
Sevilla, Esquire, of San Diego, California, is appointed to serve as
counsel for the respondents in this case.
No. 74-1656. John C. Moe, etc., et al., appellants, v. The Confed-
erated Salish and Kootenai Tribes of the Flathead Reservation, et al.;
and
No. 75-50. The Confederated Salish and Kootenai Tribes of the
Flathead Reservation et al., appellants, v. John C. Moe, etc., et al. The
joint motion to dispense with printing the appendix and for leave to
proceed on the original record is granted.
No. 74-5566. Pearl Barrett, petitioner, v. United States. The mo-
tion of the Solicitor General to permit Robert B. Reich, Esquire, to
present oral argument, pro hac vice, is granted.
No. 75–246. United States, petitioner, v. Roy C. Hopkins. The mo-
tion to dispense with printing the appendix is granted.
No. 75-436. James L. Buckley et al., appellants, v. Francis R. Valeo,
Secretary of the United States Senate, et al.; and
No. 75-437. James L. Buckley et al., appellants, v. Francis R.
Valeo, Secretary of the United States Senate, et al. The motion to re-
consider the motion of Senator Lee Metcalf for leave to permit oral
argument on his behalf, as amicus curiae, is denied.
No. 75-5014. Jefferson Doyle, petitioner, v. Ohio; and
No. 75-5015. Richard Wood, petitioner, v. Ohio. The motion to
permit Ronald L. Collins, Esquire, to present oral argument, pro hac
vice, on behalf of respondent is granted. The application for stay
of execution and enforcement of judgments and/or bail, presented to
Mr. Justice Stewart and by him referred to the Court, are denied.

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 3, 1975
No. 75-5402. Andrew J. Faison, petitioner, v. Washington. The
application for stay of enforcement of judgment and sentence, pre-
sented to Mr. Justice Douglas and by him referred to the Court, is
denied.

No. 75-420. United States and Interstate Commerce Commission,
appellants, v. The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway Company et al. Ap-
peal from the United States District Court for the Eastern District
of Virginia. In this case probable jurisdiction noted. Mr. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this matter.

to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit granted.

of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of South Dakota granted.
No. 75-382. Federal Energy Administration et al., petitioners, v.
Algonquin SNG, Inc., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit
granted. In addition to the question presented by the petition, the
parties are directed to brief and argue the applicability of the Anti-
Injunction Act, 26 U.S.C. 7421.
No. 75-5027. Russell Bryan, etc., petitioner, v. Itasca County,
Minnesota. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Minnesota granted.

of the cases in which orders or judgments are this day announced.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 11, 1975
185
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmum, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 74-1544. Richard A. Boehning, etc., et al., petitioners, v. Indi-
ana State Employees Association, Inc., et al. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh
Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 74–1569. Connecticut, petitioner, v Patrick Menillo. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Connecticut. Pe-
tition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated, and case re-
manded to the Supreme Court of Connecticut for further considera-
tion not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per
curiam. Mr. Justice White concurs in the result.
No. 75-4. Northern Indiana Public Service Company, petitioner,
v. Porter County Chapter of the Izaak Walton League of America,
Inc., et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted, judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for consideration of other contentions against the issuance of the con-
struction permit not decided by the Court of Appeals. Opinion per
curiam. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 75-139. Jimmy H. Rose, Warden, petitioner, v. Isadore
Hodges, Jr. and Andrew Lewis, Jr. On petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Motion
of respondents for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for
writ of certiorari granted. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins. Mr. Justice
Douglas would deny certiorari.
210-278-75-19

186
TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 11, 1975
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 75-434. Osage Oil and Transportation, Inc., appellant, v.
Board of Adjustment of Fayetteville, Arkansas. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Arkansas. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 75-467. John A. Wiethe, appellant, v. C. Donald Curry, Reg-
istrar. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Hamilton County,
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No.75-5055. Woodrow H. Ransonette, appellant, v. Texas. Appeal
from the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied. Mr. Justice
Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this appeal.
No. 75-5355. Neil Cody Russell, appellant v. City of Pierre, State
of South Dakota. Appeal from the Supreme Court of South Dakota.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration
or decision of this appeal.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-396. Charles Stanley Bonk. applicant. United States. The
application for a stay of the order of the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Seventh Circuit entered on October 29, 1975, presented
to Mr. Justice Marshall and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of
this application.
No. A-403. Moses LeRoy et al., applicants, v. City of Houston et al.
The application for an injunction, presented to Mr. Justice Marshall
and by him referred to the Court, is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took
no part in the consideration or decision of this application.
No. 65, Original. State of Texas, plaintiff, v. State of New Mexico.
It is ordered that the Honorable Jean Sala Breitenstein, Senior Judge
for the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit, is ap-
pointed Special Master in this case with authority to fix the time and
conditions for the filing of additional pleadings and to direct subse-
quent proceedings, and with authority to summon witnesses, issue
subpoenas, and take such evidence as may be introduced and such as
he may deem it necessary to call for. The master is directed to submit
such reports as he may deem appropriate.

TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 11, 1975
187
The master shall be allowed his actual expenses. The allowances to
him, the compensation paid to his technical, stenographic, and clerical
assistants, the cost of printing his report, and all other proper ex-
penses shall be charged against and be borne by the parties in such
proportion as the Court may hereafter direct.
It is further ordered that if the position of Special Master in this
case becomes vacant during a recess of the Court, the Chief Justice
shall have authority to make a new designation which shall have the
same effect as if originally made by the Court. The motion of the
United States for leave to intervene is referred to the Special Master.
Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of
this matter.
No. 68, Original. Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, plaintiff, v.
State of New Jersey; and
No. 69, Original. State of Maine, Commonwealth of Massachusetts,
and State of Vermont, plaintiffs, v. State of New Hampshire. The
motions for leave to file bills of complaint are set for oral argument.
Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of
these motions.
No. 74–1110. Eastern Kentucky Welfare Rights Organization et
al., petitioners, v. William E. Simon, Secretary of the Treasury, et al.;
and
No. 74-1124. William E. Simon, Secretary of the Treasury, et al.,
petitioners, v. Eastern Kentucky Welfare Rights Organization et al.
The motion of United Methodist Church et al., for leave to file a brief,
as amici curiae, is denied.
No. 74-1529. Robert J. Henderson, Superintendent, Auburn Cor-
rectional Facility, petitioner, v. Timothy G. Morgan. The motion of
the respondent for the appointment of counsel is granted and Joseph
E. Lynch, Esquire, of Auburn, New York, is appointed to serve as
counsel for the respondent in this case. Mr. Justice Douglas took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 75-95. Tennessee et al., petitioners, v. Billy Don Dunlap. The
motion to dispense with printing an appendix is granted. Mr. Justice
Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 75-129 Gary Suchy, petitioner v. United States. The motion
for leave to file an amended petition for certiorari is granted. Mr.
Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion.
No. 75-302. Len H. Small et al., appellants, v. Charles L. Pangle,
etc., et al. The motion of Illinois Association of Homes for the Aging
for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is denied.

writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Alabama denied. Mr.

196
TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 11, 1975
Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this
petition.
No. 75-202. Ferguson Reorganized School District R-2, etc., et al.,
petitioners, v. United States;
No. 75-214. Berkeley School District et al., petitioners, v. United
States; and
No. 75-215. Kinloch School District et al., petitioners, v. United
States. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit denied. The Chief Justice and Mr.
Justice Powell would grant certiorari in No. 75-214 limited to the
question whether a Federal Court has authority to fix and impose
the school tax rate upon the residents of the consolidated school dis-
trict without allowing the rate to be determined in accordance with
Missouri law. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration
or decision of these petitions.
No. 75-236. Michael Kutler, petitioner, v. United States. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with
whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall concur. Separate
statement by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 75-409. Frederick Finkbeiner, petitioner, v. Richard Mattox.
Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in
the consideration or decision of this motion and petition.
No. 75-428. Chester McKinney, petitioner, v. James C. Parsons,
Chief of Police. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr.
Justice Marshall concur. Separate statement by Mr. Justice Douglas.

RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, November 17, 1975, until
Monday, December 1, 1975.

District Court for the Northern District of California et al. Argued
by Mr. Karl S. Mayer for the petitioners and by Mr. B. E. Bergesen,
III, for the respondents.
No. 74–775. City of New Orleans et al., appellants, v. Nancy
Dukes, dba Louisiana Concessions. Argued by Mr. Joel P. Loeffelholz
for the appellants and by Mr. Joseph N. Marcal, III, for the appellee.
No. 74-895. Virginia State Board of Pharmacy et al., appellants,
v. Virginia Citizens Consumer Council, Inc., et al. Argued by Mr.
Anthony F. Troy for the appellants and by Mr. Alan B. Morrison for
the appellees.
No. 74–942. Frank L. Rizzo et al., petitioners, v. Gerald G. Goode
et al. Argued by Mr. James M. Penny, Jr. for the petitioners and by
Mr. Peter Hearn for the respondents.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
ADMISSION TO THE BAR ON ORAL MOTION
Applicant
City and State
Movant
Barbara Shore Resnicoff
New York, N.Y.
Jack I. Resnicoff.
OPINION
No. 74–54. Transamerican Freight Lines, Inc., petitioner, v. Brada
Miller Freight Systems, Inc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Blackmun. Mr. Justice Douglas concurs in the judgment.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 74-799. United States, petitioner, v. Foster Lumber Company,
Inc. Argued by Mr. Stuart A. Smith for the petitioner and by Mr.
Russell W. Baker for the respondent.
No. 74-1025. Charles A. Hines, etc., et al., petitioners, v. Anchor
Motor Freight. Inc.. et al. Argued by Mr. Niki Z. Schwartz for the
petitioners and by Mr. Bernard S. Goldfarb for the respondents.
No. 74-753. United States, petitioner, v. Herman R. Testan and
Frances L. Zarrilli. Argued by Mr. John P. Rupp for the petitioner
and by Mr. Edwin J. McDermott for the respondents.
No. 73-1869. Peter H. Beer et al., appellants, v. United States et al.
Reargued by Mr. James R. Stoner for the appellants and by Mr. Law-
rence G. Wallace for the appellee United States and by Mr. Stanley A.
Halpin, Jr., for the appellees Jackson et al.
Adjourned until Monday, November 17, 1975, at 10 o'clock.
210-278-75-21



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 17, 1975
205
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justic said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 74–1312. Mary Ann Turner, petitioner, v. Department of Em-
ployment Security and Board of Review of the Industrial Commission
of Utah. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
Utah. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated, and
case remanded to the Supreme Court of Utah for further proceedings
not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam.
Separate statement by the Chief Justice and Mr. Justice Blackmun.
Mr. Justice Rehnquist dissents.
No. 74–1451. J. H. Rose, Warden, petitioner, v. Harold Locke. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judg-
ment reversed, and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr.
Justice Marshall concurs. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart
with whom Mr. Justice Marshall concurs.
No. 75-5401. Steve Menna, petitioner, v. New York. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of New York. Motion
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certio-
rari granted. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals of New York for a determination of petitioner's double
jeopardy claim on the merits, a claim on which we express no view.
Opinion per curiam. Separate statement by Mr. Justice Brennan.
The Chief Justice and Mr. Justice Rehnquist would grant certiorari
and set case for oral argument.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 74-1165. Theodore L. Sendak, etc., appellant, v. Clyde Nihiser,
dba Movieland Drive-In Theater. Appeal from the United States Dis-

206
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 17, 1975
trict Court for the Northern District of Indiana. Judgment vacated
and case remanded to the United States District Court for the North-
ern District of Indiana for further consideration in light of Huffman
v. Pursue, Ltd., 420 U.S. 592 (1975). Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice
Marshall concur.
No. 74-1418. Madeline Buchanan et al., appellants, v. Brenda
Evans et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Dis-
trict of Delaware. Judgment affirmed. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Rehnquist with whom The Chief Justice and Mr. Justice
Powell join as to Parts I and II B.
No. 75–168. John W. Whitehead and Robert Young, appellants, v.
Darlene Westbrook, etc. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Western District of Arkansas. Judgment affirmed.
No. 75-361. Association of American Physicians and Surgeons
et al., appellants, v. F. David Mathews, Secretary of Health, Educa-
tion and Welfare. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Northern District of Illinois. Judgment affirmed.
No. 75-497. Richard Bush et al., appellants, v. James A. Sebesta,
etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Middle
District of Florida. Judgment affirmed.
No. 75-5116. Joanne Betts et al., appellants, v. F. David Mathews,
etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Dis-
trict of Vermont. Judgment affirmed.
No. 75-5408. Randolph E. Green, appellant, v. United States De-
partment of Labor et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the District of Massachusetts. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction.
No. 75–5573. Randolph E. Green, appellant, v. Department of
Public Welfare of Massachusetts et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the District of Massachusetts. The apeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 75-5481. Albert Lee Willis, appellant, v. North Carolina State
Board of Law Examiners. Appeal from the Supreme Court of North
Carolina. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-385. Ivis Long Visitor et al., applicants, v. United States.
The application for bail pending the timely filing of a petition for
writ of certiorari, presented to Mr. Justice Douglas and by him re-
ferred to the Court, is denied.

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 17, 1975
207
No. A-395. Lak Man Tom, applicant, v. Immigration and Natural-
ization Service. The motion to vacate the stay of deportation hereto-
fore entered by Mr. Justice Douglas on October 30, 1975, is granted.
No. A-432. William L. Hamling et al., applicants, v. United States.
The application for a stay of the mandate of the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, presented to Mr. Justice Brennan
and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. 74-1025. Charles A. Hines, etc., et al., petitioner, v. Anchor
Motor Freight, Inc., et al. The motion to substitute Chrya J. Cart-
wright, Administratrix of the Estate of Arthur D. Cartwright, as a
party petitioner in place of Arthur D. Cartwright, deceased, is
granted.
No. 75-110. Bernard A. Sakraida, petitioner, v. Ag Pro, Inc. The
motion of respondent to limit the grant of certiorari is denied.
No. 75-322. Louis Vernell, Jr., petitioner, v. United States. The
application for bail, presented to Mr. Justice Douglas and by him
referred to the Court, is denied.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 75-73. Francis X. Bellotti, Attorney General of Massachusetts,
et al., appellants, v. William Baird et al.; and
No. 75-109. Jane Hunerwadel, etc., appellant, v. William Baird
et al. Appeals from the United States District Court for the District
of Massachusetts. In these cases probable jurisdiction noted. Cases
consolidated and a total of one hour allotted for oral argument. The
cases are set for oral argument in tandem with Nos. 74-1151-Planned
Parenthood of Central Missouri v. Danforth and 74–1419— Danforth
v. Planned Parenthood of Central Missouri.

No. 75-491. United States, petitioner, v. Linda Agurs. Motion of
respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of
Columbia Circuit granted.

denied.

ORDER
Pursuant to the provisions of Title 28 U.S.C. Section 42, it is or-
dered that Mr. Justice Rehnquist be, and he is hereby, temporarily
assigned to the Ninth Circuit as Circuit Justice.
ASSIGNMENT ORDERS
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit from January 12, 1976, to Janu-
ary 16, 1976, and for such additional time as may be required to com-
plete unfinished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a) is ordered
entered on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit during the week of May 24, 1976,
and for such additional time as may be required to complete unfinished
business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a) is ordered entered on the
minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.
