OPINIONS
No. 74-532. Chester McKinney, petitioner, v. Alabama. On writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Alabama. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Alabama for further
proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan concurring,
insofar as the judgment of conviction is reversed, with whom
Mr. Justice White joins and Mr. Justice Stewart joins in all but
Part III. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Mr. Justice
Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 74-891. Edgar Paul, etc., et al., petitioners, v. Edward Charles
Davis III. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice White and
Mr. Justice Marshall concur. Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 74-1245. Liberty Mutual Insurance Company, petitioner, v.
Sandra Wetzel et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals with instructions to dismiss the
petitioner's appeal. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Mr. Justice
Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 74-100. Roy D. Garner, petitioner, v. United States. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Marshall concurring in the judgment with whom
Mr. Justice Brennan joins. Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.

No. 74–175. J. William Middendorf, II, et al., petitioners, v. Daniel
Edward Henry et al.; and
No. 74-5176. Daniel Edward Henry et al., petitioners, v. J. Wil-
liam Middendorf, II, Individually and in his capacity as Secretary
of the Navy, et al. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and cases re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Rehnquist. Con-
curring opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with whom Mr. Justice Black-
mun joins. Dissenting statement by Mr. Justice Stewart. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Brennan
joins. Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision
of these cases.
No. 74-1274. Abbott Laboratories et al., petitioners, v. Portland
Retail Druggists Association, Inc., etc. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment
vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Costs allowed
to petitioners to the extent of 50%. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun.
Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins. Mr. Justice
Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 74-848. Thomas U. Greer, Commander, Fort Dix Military
Reservation, et al., petitioners, v. Benjamin Spock et al. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
210-278-76- -64

486
WEDNESDAY, MARCH 24, 1976
Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Concurring opinion by Mr. Chief
Justice Burger. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Powell in Part III
with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger joins. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Marshall concurs. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Mr. Justice Stevens took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 74-728. Harold Franks and Johnnie Lee, petitioners, v. Bow-
man Transportation Company, Inc., et al. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment
affirming District Court's denial of seniority relief to class 3 reversed
and case remanded to the United States District Court for the North-
ern District of Georgia for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Opinion
by Mr. Chief Justice Burger concurring in part and dissenting in
part. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell concurring in part and dissenting
in part with whom Mr. Justice Rehnquist joins. Mr. Justice Stevens
took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

petitioners v. United States; and
No. 74-949. Mary Akin et al., petitioners, v. United States. On
writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and cases remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice
Stevens concur. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens.
No. 74-858. Hugh L. Carey, Governor of the State of New York,
et al., appellants, v. Bert Randolph Sugar and Wrestling Revue, Inc.;
and
No. 74-859. Curtis Circulation Company and Continental Casualty
Company, appellants, v. Bert Randolph Sugar and Wrestling Revue,
Inc. Appeals from the United States District Court for the Southern
District of New York. Case remanded to the United States District
Court for the Southern District of New York with directions to ab-
stain from a decision of the federal constitutional issues until the
parties have had an opportunity to obtain a construction of New York
law from the New York state courts. Opinion per curiam announced
by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr.
Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
"The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 75-676. Bowman Transportation, Inc., appellant, v. Arkansas-
Best Freight System, Inc., et al. Appeal from the United States Dis-
trict Court for the Western District of Arkansas. Judgment affirmed.
Mr. Justice Stevens would reverse.
No. 75–856. Milton Levin, appellant, v. Frank A. Gulotta, etc.,
et al.;
No. 75–972. Herbert Mildner, appellant, v. Frank A. Gulotta, etc.,
et al.; and
No. 75-1111. Julius Gerzof, aka Julius M. Gerzof, appellant, v.
Frank A. Gulotta, etc., et al. Appeals from the United States District
Court for the Eastern District of New York. Judgment affirmed. Mr.
Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice Powell would postpone considera-
tion of the question of jurisdiction to a hearing of the cases on the
merits.
No. 75-896. John Doe et al., appellants, v. Commonwealth's At-
torney for City of Richmond, et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia. Judgment
affirmed. Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice
Stevens would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral
argument.
No. 75-1124. Stephen Gaskin et al., appellants, v. Tennessee. Ap-
peal from the Court of Criminal Appeals of Tennessee, Middle Divi-
sion. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 75-6298. Darrell Lamont McKeldin, appellant, v. Tennessee.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Tennessee, Eastern Division. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
wherein the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari denied.

ORDERS IN PENDING CASES

plication for bail, presented to Mr. Justice Marshall and by him
referred to the Court, denied. Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the

OPINIONS
No. 74-1042. Ernst & Ernst, petitioner, v. Olga Hochfelder et al.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun with whom Mr. Justice
Brennan joins. Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration
or decision of this case.
No. 74-869. United States, petitioner, v. United Continental Tuna
Corporation. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Dissent-
ing opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Mr. Justice Stevens took no part
in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 73-1869. Peter H. Beer et al., appellants, v. United States et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Columbia. Judgment set aside and case remanded to the United States
District Court for the District of Columbia for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Stewart. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice White. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins. Mr.
Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of this
case.
210-278-76--66

502
TUESDAY, MARCH 30, 1976
No. 74-6293. Philip J. Goldberg, petitioner, v. United States. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States
District Court for the District of Arizona for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Brennan. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens with whom Mr.
Justice Stewart joins. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell concurring in
the judgment with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger joins.
No. 74–5968. John A. Geders, petitioner, v. United States. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Ap-
peals with directions that the case be remanded to the United States
District Court for the Middle District of Florida for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr.
Chief Justice Burger. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall
with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins. Mr. Justice Stevens took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.

of the Chicago Fire Department, petitioner, v. Francis Muscare.

Anthony G. Amsterdam for the petitioners, by John L. Hill for the

of Louisiana.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 5, 1976
505
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr.
Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice.
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 75-1024. Citizens for Parental Rights et al., appellants, v.
San Mateo County Board of Education et al. Appeal from the Court
of Appeal of California, First Appellate District. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 75-6328. Olga Ogrod, appellant, v. Walter Ogrod. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Eastern District. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 75-1128. Phoenix Newspapers, Inc. and Michael Padev, ap-
pellants, v. Wade Church. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of
Arizona, Division One. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-
tion. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied. The Chief Justice and Mr.
Justice Blackmun would grant certiorari.
No. 75–1176. Joseph M. Kadans, appellant, v. State Bar of Ne-
vada. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Nevada. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-844. James Parham, Commissioner of the Department of
Human Resources of Georgia et al., applicants, v. J. L. and J. R., etc.
Application for stay of the order and judgment of the United States
District Court for the Middle District of Georgia (Civil Action
No. 75–163-Mac), dated February 26, 1976, and March 11, 1976, re-
spectively, presented to Mr. Justice Powell and by him referred to the
Court, granted pending timely filing of appeal and final disposition
thereon by this Court. Mr. Justice Stevens would deny application.
No. 74-799. United States, petitioner, v. Foster Lumber Company,
Inc. Motion of Data Products Corporation for additional time to par-
ticipate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, or in the alternative for

No. 75-76. South Dakota, petitioner, v. Donald Opperman. Motion

MONDAY, APRIL 5, 1976
OPINIONS
517
No. 74-1269. Eugene R. Kelley, Commissioner of the Suffolk
County Police Department, petitioner, v. Edward Johnson etc. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Ap-
peals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Concurring opinion by Mr.
Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom
Mr. Justice Brennan joins. Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 74-492. Ohio, petitioner, v. Terry L. Gallagher. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Ohio. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Supreme Court of Ohio to permit that court to ex-
plicate whether or not its judgment relies on federal law. Opinion per
curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice
Blackmun concur. Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this case.
Adjourned until Monday, April 19, 1976, at 10 o'clock.

MONDAY, APRIL 19, 1976
521
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Jus-
tice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
PER CURIAM OPINION
No. 75-623. Ted Butler and Emil Peters, appellants, v. Richard C.
Dexter. Appeal from the United States District Court for the South-
ern District of Texas. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas so
that it may enter a fresh decree from which a timely appeal can, if
desired, be taken. Gonzalez v. Automatic Employees Credit Union, 419
U.S. 90 (1974); Moody v. Flowers, 387 U.S. 97 (1967). Opinion per
curiam.
No. 75-1038. Diamond National Corporation et al., appellants, v.
State Board of Equalization of California. Appeal from the Court of
Appeal of California, First Appellate District. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeal of California, First Appellate
District, for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Stevens with whom Mr. Justice Rehnquist joins.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 74-1622. William E. Kirwan, Superintendent of New York
State Police, appellant, v. Donald F. Romano. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Western District of New York.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States District
Court for the Western District of New York for further consideration
in light of Kelley v. Johnson, 425 U.S. (1976). Mr. Justice Stevens
took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
-
No. 74-5887. Lucille Maxwell and Lillie Wright, appellants, v.
Lucille Hixson, Clerk, et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Eastern District of Tennessee. Judgment affirmed.

522
MONDAY, APRIL 19, 1976
No. 75-870. Ford Motor Company, appellant, v. William T.
Coleman et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
District of Columbia. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr.
Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Stevens would note probable jurisdic-
tion and set case for oral argument.
No. 75-1118. Don Benschoter, appellant, v. First National Bank
of Lawrence et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Kansas. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 75-6169. Terrence Lovelace, appellant, v. Tennessee. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Tennessee, Eastern Division. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 75-6323. Craig E. Johnsrud, appellant, v. Minnesota Depart-
ment of Employment Services. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Minnesota. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 75-1158. National Socialist White People's Party et al., ap-
pellants, v. Joseph Walsh et al. Appeal from the United States Dis-
trict for the District of Connecticut. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the United States District Court for the District of Con-
necticut with directions to enter a fresh decree from which a timely
appeal may be taken to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit. Butler v. Dexter — U.S. (1976).
- - -
No. 75-1163. Ross Shade, appellant, v. The Public Utilities Com-
mission of the State of California et al. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of California. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision of
this appeal.
No. 75–1194. Jack Shouse et al., appellants, v. Pierce County et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Western Dis-
trict of Washington. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
United States District Court for the Western District of Washington
with directions to enter a fresh decree from which a timely appeal
may be taken to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Cir-
cuit. Gonzalez v. Automatic Employees Credit Union 419 U.S. 90
(1974).
No. 75–1210. James H. Quarles, etc., appellant, v. J. C. Goodson
et al. Appeal from the Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Fourteenth
Supreme Judicial District. The appeal is dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a peti-
tion for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.

No. 74 1447. Stephen Berger, etc., petitioner, v. Marion Aitchison,
etc. Application for stay of judgment of the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit (No. 75-7673) pending final disposi-
tion of the petition for certiorari, presented to Mr. Justice Marshall
and by him referred to the Court, denied.
No. 75-1470. Morris King Udall et al., appellants, v. Otis Bowen,
Governor of Indiana, et al. Motion to expedite consideration of appeal
denied.

No. 74-1187. Joseph Baxter et al., petitioners, v. Nicholas A.
Palmigiano. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the First Circuit; and
No. 74–1194. Jerry J. Enomoto et al., petitioners, v. John Wesley
Clutchette et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgments reversed and cases re-
manded to the respective Courts of Appeals for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
White. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan concurring in part and dis-
senting in part with whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins. Mr. Justice
Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 74–1047. Carla A. Hills, Secretary of Housing and Urban
Development, petitioner, v. Dorothy Gautreaux et al. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Cir-
cuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Concurring
opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and
Mr. Justice White join. Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this case.

writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr.
Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice

APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 75–1493. Arch A. Moore, Jr., appellant, James McCartney, Sec-
retary of State of West Virginia, et al. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Appeals of West Virginia. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question.

(JOURNAL)
FRIDAY, APRIL 23, 1976
551
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Jus-
tice Stevens.
ORDER IN PENDING CASES
No. 75-436. James L. Buckley et al., appellants, v. Francis R.
Valeo, Secretary of the United States Senate, et al.; and
No. 75-437. James L. Buckley et al., appellants, v. Francis R.
Valeo, Secretary of the United States Senate, et al. Motion of Jimmy
Carter, Frank Church, Fred Harris, Henry M. Jackson, Ronald Rea-
gan, Morris K. Udall, and George C. Wallace for leave to intervene
and the following motions relating thereto: motion for recall and
modification of judgment and other equitable relief; motion to ad-
vance and expedite; and motion of the Democratic National Com-
mittee for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, denied.
Mr. Justice Powell, concurring:
I concur in the Court's denial of the petition to intervene. As these
cases have been remanded to the Court of Appeals, jurisdiction with
respect to relief sought by new parties at this time is vested in that
court.
Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of
these motions.
Adjourned until Monday at 10 o'clock.
210-278-76—76

7

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 26, 1976
553
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr.
Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 75-805. Civil Service Commission of New York et al., appel-
lants v. Marie Snead. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Southern District of New York. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the United States District Court for the Southern Dis-
trict of New York with instructions to dismiss appellee's complaint in-
sofar as it sought relief against the appellants. Opinion per curiam.
Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall and
Mr. Justice Blackmun would affirm without hearing oral argument.
No. 75-1106. National Bank of North America, petitioner, v.
Associates of Obstetrics and Female Surgery, Inc., et al. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Utah. Petition for writ of
certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the Su-
preme Court of Utah for further proceedings not inconsistent with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Concurring opinion by
Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 75-93. Town of Sorrento Municipal Democratic Executive
Committee et al., appellants, v. Glynn Reine et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Middle District of Louisiana.
Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist
would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
No. 75-898. Linda Marie Sutherland et al., appellants, v. Illinois.
Appeal from the Appellate Court of Illinois, Third District. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice Stevens would note
probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
No. 75-1250. Standard Oil Company, appellant, v. Robert G.
Sharpe, Motor Vehicle Comptroller of Mississippi. Appeal from the
210-278-76- -77

554
MONDAY, APRIL 26, 1976
Supreme Court of Mississippi. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 75-1470. Morris King Udall et al., appellants, v. Otis Bowen,
Governor of Indiana, et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Southern District of Indiana. Judgment affirmed.
No. 75-6296. William L. Harris, appellant, v. City of Columbus,
Ohio. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Ohio. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the ap-
peal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 75-35. Russell E. Lash, warden, et al., petitioners, v. Marvin
Lee Aikens et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Motion of respondents for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Ap-
peals for further consideration in light of Baxter v. Palmigiano, 425
U.S. (1976). Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration
or decision of this case.
-
No. 75–914. George Wallace, Sr., et al., petitioners, v. J. P. House,
etc., et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further consideration in light of East Carroll Parish School
Board v. Marshall, 424 U.S. · (1976) and Public Law 94-73 (Au-
gust 6, 1975).
-
No. 75-6106. Douglas Hill, petitioner, v. United States. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Sixth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and
petition for writ of certiorari granted. Upon the representation of the
Solicitor General set forth in his memorandum for the United States
filed April 8, 1976, judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further consideration in light of the position presently
asserted by the government.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-910. Roger Alstair William Fry, applicant, v. United
States. Application for pretrail bond and for stay of trial, presented
to Mr. Justice Brennan and by him referred to the Court, denied.
No. A-923. Stephen Berger, Commissioner of Social Services of
New York, applicant, v. Elizabeth Linda Klein et al. Application for

MONDAY, APRIL 26, 1976
555
stay of judgment of the United States District Court for the Eastern
District of New York, case No. 72 C 386, presented to Mr. Justice
Marshall and by him referred to the Court, denied.
No. 31, Original. State of Utah, plaintiff, v. United States. Report
of Special Master received and ordered filed. Exceptions, if any, with
supporting briefs to the Report may be filed by the parties within 45
days. Reply briefs, if any, to such exceptions may be filed within 30
days. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision
of this order.
No. 74-1023. Henry W. Kerr et al., petitioners, v. United States
District Court for the Northern District of California et al. Motion
of petitioners for leave to file a supplemental brief, after argument,
denied. Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this motion.
No. 75-5952. Deta Mona Trimble and Jessie Trimble, appellants,
v. Joseph Roosevelt Gordon et al. Motion of appellees King et al. for
leave to proceed further herein in forma pauperis granted. The Chief
Justice, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist would deny the motion.

of Education et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Michigan.

of Virginia. Motion of Virginia Seafood Council et al. for leave to
file a brief, as amici curiae, granted. In this case probable jurisdiction
noted. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief expressing the
views of the United States.

Ohio. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Cuyahoga County.
Motion of appellant for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
In this case probable jurisdiction noted.

MONDAY, APRIL 26, 1976
RECESS ORDER
561
The Court will take a recess from Monday, May 3, 1976, until Mon-
day, May 17, 1976.
ORDERED:
ORDERS
1. That the Rules of Criminal Procedure for the United States Dis-
trict Courts be, and they hereby are, amended by including therein
Rule 40.1 and amendments to Rules 6(e), 6(f), 23(b), 23(c), 24(b),
41 (a), 41 (c), and 50 (b).
2. That the amendments and addition to the rules of procedure shall
take effect on August 1, 1976, and shall govern all criminal proceed-
ings thereafter commenced and, insofar as just and practicable, in
proceedings then pending.
3. That The Chief Justice be, and he hereby is, authorized to trans-
mit to the Congress the amendments and addition to the Rules of
Criminal Procedure in accordance with the provision of Title 18,
United States Code, Sections 3771 and 3772.
ORDERED:
1. That the rules and forms governing proceedings in the United
States District Courts under Section 2254 and Section 2255 of Title
28, United States Code, as approved by the Judicial Conference of the
United States be, and they hereby are, prescribed pursuant to Section
2072 of Title 28, United States Code and Sections 3771 and 3772 of
Title 18, United States Code.
2. That the aforementioned rules and forms shall take effect August
1, 1976, and shall be applicable to all proceedings then pending except
to the extent that in the opinion of the court their application in a par-
ticular proceeding would not be feasible or would work injustice.
3. That THE CHIEF JUSTICE be, and he hereby is, authorized to
transmit the aforementioned rules and forms governing Section 2254
and Section 2255 proceedings to the Congress in accordance with the
provisions of Section 2072 of Title 28 and Sections 3771 and 3772 of
Title 18, United States Code.
ORDERED:
1. That Rules 112, 121, 205, 306, 404, 704, 712, 755, 801, 805, 914,
917 and Official Forms No. 6 and No. 26 implementing Chapters I-VII
of the Bankruptcy Act, Rules 11-24, 11-61, and 11-62 implementing
Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act, and Rules 13-203, 13-204, 13-206,
13-207, 13-302, 13-303, 13-304, 13-305, 13-307, 13-701, 13-901 and Offi-
cial Forms No. 13-5 and No. 13-7 implementing Chapter XIII of the
Bankruptcy Act as annexed hereto, are amended effective August 1,
1976.
210-278-76-78

562
MONDAY, APRIL 26, 1976
2. That the aforementioned amendments shall be applicable to pro-
ceedings then pending except to the extent that in the opinion of the
court their application in a particular proceeding then pending would
not be feasible or would work injustice, in which event the former
procedure applies.
3. That Rule 744.1 of the General Rules of Bankruptcy Procedure
is hereby abrogated as no longer necessary.
4. That THE CHIEF JUSTICE be, and he hereby is, authorized to
transmit the aforementioned amendments to rules and forms imple-
menting Chapters I-VII, XI, and XIII of the Bankruptcy Act to the
Congress in accordance with the provisions of Title 28. United States
Code, Section 2075.
ORDERED:
1. That the rules and forms as approved by the Judicial Conference
of the United States and annexed hereto, to be known as the Chapter
VIII Rules and Official Chapter VIII Forms, be, and they hereby are,
prescribed pursuant to Section 2075, Title 28, United States Code, to
govern the forms of process, writs, pleadings and motions and the
practice and procedure under Chapter VIII of the Bankruptcy Act.
in the proceedings and to the extent set forth therein, in the United
States district courts, the District Court for the District of the Canal
Zone, and the District Courts of Guam and the Virgin Islands.
2. That the aforementioned Chapter VIII Rules and Official Chapter
VIII Forms shall take effect on August 1, 1976, and shall be applicable
to proceedings then pending except to the extent that in the opinion of
the court their application in a particular proceeding then pending
would not be feasible or would work injustice, in which event the
former procedure applies.
3. That General Order in Bankruptcy 49 heretofore prescribed by
this Court be, and it hereby is, abrogated, effective August 1, 1976.
4. That THE CHIEF JUSTICE be, and he hereby is, authorized to trans-
mit the aforementioned new Chapter VIII Rules and Official Chapter
VIII Forms to the Congress in accordance with the provisions of Title
28, U.S.C. § 2075.
ORDERED:
1. That the rules and forms as approved by the Judicial Conference
of the United States and annexed hereto, to be known as the Chapter
IX Rules and Official Chapter IX Forms, be, and they hereby are,
prescribed pursuant to Section 2075, Title 28. United States Code, to
govern the forms of process, writs, pleadings and motions and the
practice and procedure under Chapter IX of the Bankruptcy Act, in
the proceedings and to the extent set forth therein, in the United States

MONDAY, APRIL 26, 1976
563
district courts, the District Court for the District of the Canal Zone,
and the District Courts of Guam and the Virgin Islands.
2. That the aforementioned Chapter IX Rules and Official Chapter
IX Forms shall take effect on August 1, 1976, and shall be applicable
to proceedings then pending except to the extent that in the opinion
of the court their application in a particular proceeding then pending
would not be feasible or would work injustice, in which event the
former procedure applies.
3. That THE CHIEF JUSTICE be, and he hereby is, authorized to trans-
mit the aforementioned new Chapter IX Rules and Official Chapter
IX Forms to the Congress in accordance with the provisions of Title
28, U.S.C. § 2075.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice

The Chief Justice said:

ice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 75–1146. Paul Bradley et al., appellants, v. Franklin J. Lund-
ing, Jr., Chairman, State Board of Elections Commissioners, et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 75-1165. American Trucking Associations, Inc., appellant, v.
United States et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the District of Columbia. Judgment affirmed.
No. 75-1356. Herman L. Driskell et al., appellants, v. Edwin W.
Edwards, etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Western District of Louisiana. Judgment affirmed.
No. 75–1316. City of Canton, Ohio, appellant, v. Ira L. Whitman,
Director of Environmental Protection of Ohio. Appeal from the Su-
preme Court of Ohio. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 75–5898. Noble C. Beasley, petitioner, v. United States. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition
for writ of certiorari granted. Upon the representation of the Solicitor
General set forth in his memorandum for the United States filed
April 14, 1976, judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further consideration in light of the position presently
asserted by the government.
No. 75-6217. Charles Melvin Riggins, petitioner, v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Fifth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Upon the representa-
210-278-76-82

MONDAY, MAY 3, 1976
tion of the Solicitor General set forth in his memorandum for the
United States filed April 27, 1976, judgment vacated and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light of
the position presently asserted by the government.

No. 67, Original. State of Idaho ex rel. Cecil D. Andrus, Governor,
Wayne L. Kidwell, Attorney General, Joseph C. Greenley, Director,

Francis L. Zarrilli. Motion of respondents to retax costs denied. Mr.

motion.

file a brief, as amicus curiae, denied.

International Tours, Inc. The Solicitor General is invited to file a
brief in this case expressing the views of the United States.

OPINIONS
No. 74-5808. Abraham Francis, petitioner, v. C. Murray Hender-
son, Warden. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Stewart. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Mr.
Justice Marshall took no part in the decision of this case. Mr. Justice
Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 74–676. W. J. Estelle, Jr., Director, Texas Department of Cor-
rections, petitioner, v. Harry Lee Williams. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Powell
with whom Mr. Justice Stewart joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Marshall concurs. Mr. Justice
Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 74-1318. Drew Municipal Separate School District et al., peti-
tioners, v. Katie Mae Andrews et al. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Writ of certi-
orari dismissed as improvidently granted. Opinion per curiam an-
nounced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.

602
MONDAY, MAY 3, 1976
No. 75-130. Robert J. Quinn, Individually and as Commissioner of
the Chicago Fire Department, petitioner, v. Francis Muscare. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh
Circuit. Writ of certiorari dismissed as improvidently granted. Opin-
ion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Mr. Justice
Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
Adjourned until Monday, May 17, 1976, at 10 o'clock.

WEDNESDAY, MAY 19, 1976
607
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr.
Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Jus-
tice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 75-1184. Peggy J. Connor et al., petitioners, v. J. P. Coleman,
United States Circuit Judge, et al. On motion for leave to file peti-
tion for writ of mandamus. Motion for leave to file petition for writ
of mandamus granted. Since the District Court may be expected to
conform its proceedings to the views expressed in the opinion of the
Court consideration of the petition for writ of mandamus continued
to June 17, 1976. Opinion per curiam. The Chief Justice concurs in
granting motion but does not joint in the opinion. Separate statement
by Mr. Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 75-926. Phillip Elwon Walters, appellant, v. California. Ap-
peal from the Court of Appeal of California, Fourth Appellate
District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a subtantial federal
question.
No. 75-1279. Henry Esteva, appellant, v. Edward F. Boardman.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal
was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 75-1360. Dan Francis, appellant, v. Chrysler Corporation et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Ohio. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 75-6079. Glenda Cash, etc., appellant, v. F. David Mathews,
Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Northern District of Georgia.
Judgment affirmed.
210-278-76-85

608
WEDNESDAY, MAY 19, 1976
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 75-5806. John Newman, petitioner, v. C. Murray Henderson,
Warden. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment
vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further con-
sideration in light of Lefkowitz v. Newsome, 420 U.S. 283, 292 n. 9
and Francis v. Henderson, 425 U.S.
- slip op. at 6n. 5 (1976).
Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.
No. 75-700. United States et al., petitioners, v. John L. Beattie, Jr.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted,
judgment vacated, and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further consideration in light of Fisher v. United States and Kasmir
v. United States, 425 U.S. (1976).

of Appeals for the Second Circuit, presented to Mr. Justice Brennan
and by him referred to the Court, denied.

ment entered.

January 28, 1976, denied.

OPINIONS
No. 74-1608. National Association for the Advancement of Colored
People et al., petitioners, v. Federal Power Commission; and

630
WEDNESDAY, MAY 19, 1976
No. 74–1619. Federal Power Commission, petitioner, v. National
Association for the Advancement of Colored People et al. On writs
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District
of Columbia Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Stewart. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Opinion by Mr.
Chief Justice Burger concurring in the judgment. Mr. Justice Mar-
shall took no part in the consideration or decision of these cases.
No. 74-1481. American Motorists Insurance Company, appellant,
v. Virgil B. Starnes. Appeal from the Court of Civil Appeals of
Texas, Tenth Supreme Judicial District. Judgment affirmed. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Brennan. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger concur-
ring in the judgment with whom Mr. Justice Rehnquist joins.
No. 75-145. The Northern Cheyenne Tribe, petitioner, v. William
Hollowbreast et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Brennan. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun.
No. 74–1329. Edward H. Hynes et al., appellants, v. The Mayor
and Council of the Borough of Oradell et al. Appeal from the Su-
preme Court of New Jersey. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Supreme Court of New Jersey for further proceedings not in-
consistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Chief
Justice Burger. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan concurring in part
with whom Mr. Justice Marshall concurs. Mr. Justice Stevens took
no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 74–754. United States, petitioner, v. Roy Mandujano. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Ap-
peals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Brennan concurring in the judgment with whom Mr. Justice Marshall
joins. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart concurring in the judgment
with whom Mr. Justice Blackmun joins. Mr. Justice Stevens took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
Adjourned until Monday, May 24, 1976, at 10 o'clock.
☑

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MAY 24, 1976
631
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Berger, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice
White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Rehn-
quist, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said;
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 70, Original. State of Arizona, plaintiff, v. State of New
Mexico. On motion for leave to file bill of complaint. Motion for leave
to file bill of complaint denied. Opinion per curiam. Concurring
opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens.
No. 75-1097. South Prairie Construction Company, petitioner, v.
Local No. 627, International Union of Operating Engineers, AFL-
CIO, et al.; and
No. 75-1243. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. Local
No. 627, International Union of Operating Engineers, AFL-CIO,
et al. On petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Petitions for writs
of certiorari granted. Judgment affirmed in part and vacated in part
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 75-624. Evan E. Jones, Jr., etc., et al., appellants, v. T
H, etc. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Southern District of Utah. Motion of appellee for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis granted. Without indicating any views on whether
the District Court's decision on the constitutional issue was sound,
judgment affirmed insofar as it invalidated the challenged regulation
of the Utah Division of Family Services as inconsistent with the
Social Security Act. The Chief Justice and Mr. Justice Rehnquist
would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
No. 75-6178. W. David Faircloth, appellant, v. Old National Bank
☐ of Washington. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Washington. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr.
Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Stevens would note probable juris-
diction and set case for oral argument.
210-278-76-87

632
MONDAY, MAY 24, 1976
No. 75-6543. Thida Annie Wong et al., appellants, v. Board of
Trustees, California State University and Colleges. Appeal from the
Court of Appeal of California, First Appellate District. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice
Brennan and Mr. Justice White would note probable jurisdiction and
set case for oral argument.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 74-1650. Environmental Protection Agency, petitioner, v. St.
Joe Minerals Corporation. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Petition for
writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals with instructions to dismiss cause as moot.
No. 75–182. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, peti-
titioner, v. Jersey Central Power & Light Co. et al. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third
Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in
light of Franks v. Bowman Transportation Co., Inc., 424 U.S.
(1976). Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this case.
No. 75–649. F. David Mathews, Secretary of Health, Education
and Welfare, petitioner, v. Arlene Mattern et al. On peition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Cir-
cuit. Motion of respondents for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in
light of Mathews v. Eldridge, 424 U.S. ————— (1976).
No. 75–1234. F. David Mathews, Secretary of Health, Education
and Welfare, petitioner, v. Evelyn Elliott et al. On petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Motion of respondents for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in
light of Mathews v. Eldridge, 424 U.S.
-
(1976).

denied.

No. 75-6527. James Ingraham, by his mother and next friend,
Eloise Ingraham, et al., petitioners, v. Willie J. Wright, I, et al. Mo-
tion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Cir-
cuit granted limited to Questions 1 and 2 presented by the petition
which read as follows:
"1. Does the infliction of severe corporal punishment upon public
school students, absent notice of the charges for which punishment is
to be inflicted and an opportunity to be heard, violate the due process
clause of the Fourteenth Amendment?
"2. Does the cruel and unusual punishment clause of the Eight
Amendment apply to the administration of discipline through severe
corporal punishment inflicted by public school teachers and adminis-
trators upon public school children?"

MONDAY, MAY 24, 1976
CERTIORARI DENIED

No. 75-6672. Jose Castro, petitioner, v. Vincent J. Regan, Super-
intendent, New Jersey State Prison. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit denied.
No. 75-6695. Freddie M. Johnson, petitioner, v. Robert L. Johnson,
Superintendent, State Correctional Institution. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit
denied.
No. 74-1064. William A. Waters and Donald Samuels, petitioners,
v. Wisconsin Steel Works of International Harvester Company et al.;
and
No. 74-1350. United Order of American Bricklayers and Stone
Masons, Local 21, petitioner, v. William A. Waters et al. Petitions for
writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the

MONDAY, MAY 24, 1976
641
Seventh Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of these petitions.
No. 74-1349. Local 862, International Union, United Automobile,
Aerospace and Agricultural Implement Workers of America, peti-
tioner, v. Ford Motor Company et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit denied. Mr.
Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of this
petition.
No. 75-465. Jersey Central Power & Light Co., petitioner, v. Equal
Employment Opportunity Commission et al. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit
denied. Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this petition.
No. 75-1174. Time, Inc., petitioner, v. Michael S. Virgil. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Stewart
would grant certiorari.
No. 75–1226. Hyman C. Slepicoff, dba Graduate Enterprises, peti-
tioner, v. United States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Stewart and
Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 75–1240. Thomas Rodriguez and Angel Manuel Santana, pe-
titioners, v. United States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit denied. Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall would grant
certiorari.
No. 75-1270. Associated Dry Goods Corporation, petitioner, v.
Commissioner of Taxation of Minnesota. Petition for writ of certio-
rari to the Supreme Court of Minnesota denied. Mr. Justice Blackmun
took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 75-1427. Air Line Pilots Association, International, petitioner,
v. Ralph Wells et al. Motion of respondent Wells for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITION FOR WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS DENIED
No. 75-6667. Richard Emmett Smiley, petitioner, v. Robert Firth,
Judge, United States District Court for the Central District of Cali-
fornia. Motion for leave to file petition for writ of habeas corpus
denied.

642
MONDAY, MAY 24, 1976
LEAVE TO FILE PETITION FOR WRIT OF MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 75-6556. Albert H. Carter, petitioner, v. Woodrow Seals,
United States District Judge, Southern District of Texas. Motion
for leave to file petition for writ of mandamus denied.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITION FOR WRIT OF PROHIBITION DENIED
No. 75-6528. Roy B. Foster, petitioner, v. Walter E. Gallawa et al.
Motion for leave to file petition for writ of prohibition and/or
mandamus denied.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 75-1024. Citizens for Parental Rights et al., appellants, v. San
Mateo County Board of Education et al.;
No. 75-1038. Diamond National Corporation et al., appellants, v.
State Board of Equalization of California.;
No. 75–1061. Western Grain Company, appellant, v. Alabama;
No. 75-1068. Lea Associates, Inc., petitioner, v. United States;
No. 75-1169. James C. Gabriel, petitioner, v. Betty Levin et al.;
No. 75-5895. Tommy Pritchett et al., petitioners, v. Georgia;
No. 75-6384. Archie Taylor, petitioner, v. Alabama; and
No. 75-6442. Jessie D. McDonald, petitioner, v. Tennessee. Peti-
tions for rehearing denied.
No. 75-1163. Ross Shade, appellant, v. The Public Utilities Com-
mission of the State of California et al. Petition for rehearing denied.
Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision of
this petition.
No. 75-6024. Leon Morgan, petitioner, v. United States. Motion
for leave to file petition for rehearing denied.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from today until Tuesday, June 1, 1976.

MONDAY, MAY 24, 1976
OPINIONS
No. 74-895. Virginia State Board of Pharmacy et al., appellants,
v. Virginia Citizens Consumer Council, Inc., et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Concurring
opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Concurring opinion by Mr.
Justice Stewart. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Mr.
Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of this
case.
No. 74-1452. Hospital Building Company, petitioner, v. Trustees
of the Rex Hospital et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Marshall.
No. 73–1288. Alfred Dunhill of London, Inc., petitioner, v. The
Republic of Cuba et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
White Part III of which is joined only by Mr. Chief Justice Burger,
Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Concurring opinion
by Mr. Justice Powell. Concurring statement by Mr. Justice Stevens.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Blackmun join.
Adjourned until Tuesday, June 1, 1976, at 10 o'clock.
Х

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, JUNE 1, 1976
659
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 74-1335. Donald Ringgold and John C. Ashhurst, appellants,
v. Borough of Collingswood. Appeal from the Supreme Court of New
Jersey. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal ques-
tion. Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice
Blackmun would vacate judgment and remand case to the Supreme
Court of New Jersey for further consideration in light of Hynes v.
Mayor and Council of Borough of Oradel, 425 U.S. — (1976). Mr.
Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of this
case.
No. 75-1410. James Willie Poindexter appellant, v. Texas. Appeal
from the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 75-1449. Celestia Elizabeth Williams, appellant, v. Boyce
Duane Williams. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Oklahoma. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari denied.
No. 75-6574. Rebecca Abrevaya, appellant, v. Norman Behar.
Appeal from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of New
York, Second Judicial Department. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as
a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 75–1498. William Jonathan Golz et ux., appellants, v. Chil-
dren's Bureau of New Orleans, Inc. Appeal from the Supreme Court
of Louisiana. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
210-278-76- -89

660
TUESDAY, JUNE 1, 1976
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 75–6202. Lanis Hurst, petitioner, v. United States. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and pe-
tition for writ of certiorari granted. Upon the representation of the
Solicitor General set forth in his memorandum for the United States
filed May 7, 1976, judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further consideration in light of the position presently
asserted by the Government.
No. 75-6265. Eugene Harris, petitioner, v. Jimmy H. Rose, War-
den. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration
in light of Estelle v. Williams, 425 U.S. — (1976).
No. 75-6578. James McGrath, petitioner, v. Douglas Vinzant, Su-
perintendent, Massachusetts Correctional Institution, et al. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the First Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari dismissed. Molinaro v.
New Jersey, 396 U. S. 365 (1970).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-979. Sheldon Yavitz, applicant, v. United States. Application
for stay of order of confinement or for bail pending appeal in the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, presented to
Mr. Justice Stewart and by him referred to the Court, denied.
No. A-1021. Bert Shulimson, Director of Division of Welfare of
Missouri, et al., applicants, v. Hariece Lewis, etc. Application for stay
of mandate of the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth
Circuit, presented to Mr. Justice Blackmun and by him referred to
the Court, granted pending the timely filing and disposition of a pe-
tition for writ of certiorari.
No. 75-478. Parker Seal Company, petitioner, v. Paul Cummins.
Motion of International Association of Machinists and Aerospace
Workers for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted.
No. 75-628. Curtis Craig et al., appellants, v. David Boren, etc., et
al. Motion to add Donald Basil Bardwell as a party appellant denied.
No. 75-804. Richard T. Hill, petitioner, v. United Brotherhood of
Carpenters and Joiners of America, Local 25, et al. Motion to substi-
tute Joy A. Farmer, Special Administrator, as the party petitioner in
place of Richard T. Hill, decreased, granted.

TUESDAY, JUNE 1, 1976
661
No. 75-946. City of Madison, Joint School District No. 8, et al.,
appellants, v. Wisconsin Employment Relations Commission et al.
Motion of The National Right to Work Legal Defense Foundation for
leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted.
No. 75-1180. Division of Vocational Rehabilitation, Department
of Health and Rehabilitative Services of Florida, et al., petitioners, v.
Wilbur Kenyard Thomas et al. Motion of counsel for respondent
Thomas for award of attorney's fees denied.
No. 75-1447. Stephen Berger, etc., petitioner, v. Marion Aitchison,
etc.; and
No. 75–1452. Kimbell, Inc., dba Foodway Furr's, Inc., et al., appel-
ants, v. Employment Security Commission of New Mexico et al. So-
licitor General invited to file briefs in these cases expressing the views
of the United States.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 75–1261. Earl L. Butz, Secretary of Agriculture, appellant, v.
Karen Hein et al.; and
No. 75–1355. Kevin J. Burns, etc., et al., appellants, v. Karen Hein
et al. Appeals from the United States District Court for the Southern
District of Iowa. Motion of appellee Hein for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis granted. In these cases probable jurisdiction noted,
cases consolidated, and a total of one hour allotted for oral argument.
CERTIORARI GRANTED

writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit granted.

Appeals granted.

Bond, etc., et al. Motion of respondents for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court

no part in the consideration or decision of this motion and petition.

and Welfare, petitioner v. Mister Sanders. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit
granted. Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration or
decision of this petition.

REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 75-1072. Joe Linden Blanton, petitioner, v. United States;

No. 75–1292. Theodore Koehler, Warden, petitioner, v. Enoch
Chism;
No. 75-5922. Arthur Decar Ferris, petitioner, v. Illinois;
No. 75-6234. Bruce Alter McCollin, petitioner, v. Kenneth D. Britt,
Superintendent, California State Penitentiary;
No. 75–6294. John M. Reed, petitioner, v. Del Chemical Corpora-
tion et al.; and
No. 75-6343. Samuel Gravina, petitioner, v. Switzerland et al.
Petitions for rehearing denied.
No. 74-940. Colorado River Water Conservation District et al.,
petitioners, v. United States; and
No. 74-949. Mary Akin et al., petitioners, v. United States. Motion
of Southern Ute Indian Tribe et al., for leave to file a petition for
rehearing, as amici curiae, denied.
ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Appeals for the First Circuit from September 8 to September 15,
1976, and for such additional time as may be required to complete un-
finished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a) is ordered entered on
the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from today until Monday June 7, 1976.

OPINIONS
No. 73–1046. F. David Mathews, Secretary of the Department of
Health, Education and Welfare, appellant, r. Santiago Diaz et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Southern Dis-
trict of Florida. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the Southern District of Florida for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Stevens.
No. 73–1596. Robert E. Hampton, Chairman of the United States
Civil Service Commission, et al., petitioners, . Mow Sun Wong et al.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens.
Concurring statement by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice
Marshall joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist with
whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice
Blackmun join.
No. 74-1124. William E. Simon, Secretary of the Treasury, et al.,
petitioners v. Eastern Kentucky Welfare Rights Organization et al.;
and
No. 74-1110. Eastern Kentucky Welfare Rights Organization et
al., petitioners, v. William E. Simon, Secretary of the Treasury, et al.
On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment vacated and cases remanded
to the United States District Court for the District of Columbia with
instructions to dismiss the complaint. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell.
Concurring statement by Mr. Justice Stewart. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Brennan concurring the judgment and dissenting with whom Mr. Jus-
tice Marshall joins. Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of these cases.
No. 74-1270. Russell Train, Administrator of the Environmental
Protection Agency, et al., petitioners, v. Colorado Public Interest
Research Group, Inc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conform-
ity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall.
Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.

TUESDAY, JUNE 1, 1976
683
No. 74-768. Clarence Brown, petitioner, v. General Services Ad-
ministration et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Stewart. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens with whom
Mr. Justice Brennan joins. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 74–1599. Jewell D. Chandler, petitioner, v. Richard L. Roude-
bush, etc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart.
No. 75-328. United States, petitioner, v. Joseph V. Orleans et al.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
Adjourned until Monday, June 7, 1976, at 10 o'clock.



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 7, 1976
685
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Jus-
tice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 75-1382. The Omaha National Bank, petitioner, v. Nebraskans
for Independent Banking, Inc., et al. On petition for writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.
Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for reconsideration in light of
Legislative Bill 763. Opinion per curiam.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73–1915. Lester L. Perkins, appellant, v. Howard Smith et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Maryland. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice
Marshall would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral
argument.
No. 74-216. United States Civil Service Commission et al., appel-
lants, v. Jose Antonio Santin Ramos and Jose Joaquin Cabrera
Gomez. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District
of Puerto Rico. Motion of appellees for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. Insofar as the judgment of the United States Dis-
trict Court for the District of Puerto Rico declares 5 C.F.R. § 8338.101
to be invalid, judgment affirmed. Hampton v. Mow Sun Wong, 425
U.S.
(1976). Because the current Appropriation Act's exclu-
sion of payments to aliens for positions within the United States does
not apply to Cuban nationals like the plaintiff-appellee, P. L. 94–91,
89 Stat. 458, the District Court is directed to vacate as moot that part
of its judgment holding § 601 of the Treasury Postal Service and
General Government Appropriation Act of 1973, P. L. 92-351, un-
constitutional.
Insofar as appellants seek to appeal from the District Court's hold-
ing that 7 U.S.C. § 1961 (b) (1) and FHA Instruction 441.2 are un-
constitutional, the appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. The
210-278-76– -91

686
MONDAY, JUNE 7, 1976
District Court failed to enter an injunction from which an appeal
lies under 28 U.S.C. § 1253 and the notice of appeal was not filed
within 30 days of any arguably appealable order. See 28 U.S.C. § 2101
(a), (b). The District Court may reconsider its holding in light of
Hampton v. Mow Sun Wong, 425 U.S.
(1976) and Mathews v.
Diaz, 425 U.S.
(1976) before it enters a final judgment.
No. 75-336. California State Board of Pharmacy et al., appellants,
v. Shirley Terry, etc. et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Northern District of California. Judgment affirmed.
No. 75-1496. Charles Ross Carino, appellant, v. Ella T. Grasso,
Governor of the State of Connecticut. Appeal from the United States.
District Court for the District of Connecticut. Judgment affirmed.
No. 75-1119. Film Follies, Inc., appellant, v. Harl Haas, etc., et al.
Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Oregon. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice
Marshall concur.
No. 75-1430. Renault Robinson, appellant, v. City of Chicago.
Appeal from the Appellate Court of Illinois, First District. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice
Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall would note probable jurisdiction
and set case for oral argument.
No. 75-1539. Board of Optometry, State of California, appellant,
2. California Citizens Action Group et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Central District of California. Motion
of American Optometric Association for leave to file a brief, as amicus |
curiae, granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the Central District of California for further
consideration in light of Virginia Board of Pharmacy v. Virginia
Citizens Consumer Council, Inc., 425 U.S. — (1976).
-
No. 75-6605. Thomas B. White, appellant, v. Nelson P. Guild.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Cir-
cuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari denied.
No. 75-6640. Kattie Mae Price, appellant, v. Iowa. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Iowa. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
final judgment (28 U.S.C. 1257).
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 74-1600. Anthony M. Salone, Jr., petitioner, v. United States
et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of

Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted,
judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further consideration in light of Chandler v. Roudebush, 425 U.S.
(1976).

Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied.
No. 75-6623. Albert H. Carter, petitioner, v. The Money Tree
Company. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit denied.

for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, First Ap-
pellate District, denied.

Secretary, Florida Department of Offender Rehabilitation. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit denied.
No. 75-6627. Clifford Loren David, petitioner, v. California. Pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California,

MONDAY, JUNE 7, 1976
No. 75-6655. Anderson L. Riggins, petitioner, v. Larry Meachum.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the First Circuit denied.
No. 75–928. W. J. Estelle, Jr., Director, Texas Department of Cor-
rections. et al., petitioners, v. William Wayne Justice, U.S. District
Judge for the Eastern District of Texas, et al. Motion of respondents
Ruiz et al. for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist with
whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice Powell join.
No. 75-6300. Carlos Ledesma Garduno, Petitioner, v. California.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California,
Fourth Appellate District, denied. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Jus-
tice Marshall would grant certiorari.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 75-6155. Douglas William Hicks, petitioner, v. United States;
No. 75-6325. F. Christman Dawn, etc., petitioner, v. Sterling Drug,
Inc., et al. and
No. 75–6397. Robert W. Lyon, petitioner. v. California. Petitions
for rehearing denied.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Thursday, June 10, 1976. until
Monday. June 14. 1976.

OPINIONS
No. 75-455. Ralph Nader, petitioner, v. Allegheny Airlines, Inc.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Concurring
opinion by Mr. Justice White.
No. 75–250. City of Charlotte et al., petitioners, v. Local 660,
International Association of Firefighters et al. On writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judg-
ment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Marshall. Separate statement by Mr. Justice Stewart con-
curring in the judgment.
No. 74-220. Ed W. Hancock, Attorney General of Kentucky,
petitioner, v. Russell E. Train, Administrator, Environmental Protec-
tion Agency, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr.
Justice White. Dissenting statement by Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr.
Justice Rehnquist.
No. 74–1435. The Environmental Protection Agency et al., peti-
tioners, v. California ex rel. State Water Resources Control Board et
al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Dissenting statement by
Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
No. 74–1492. Walter E. Washington, etc., et al., petitioners, v.
Alfred E. Davis et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment reversed.
Opinion by Mr. Justice White joined in Parts I and II by Mr. Justice

MONDAY, JUNE 7, 1976
701
Stewart. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens. Dissenting opin-
ion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins.
No. 75–342. Federal Power Commission, petitioner, v. Conway
Corporation et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Mr. Justice White.
No. 75–268. Hyman Radzanower, petitioner, v. Touche, Ross & Co.,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Second Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stew-
art. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens.
No. 74–1107. Francis Leo Cappaert et al., petitioners, v. United
States et al; and
No. 74-1304. Nevada ex. rel. Roland D. Westergard, State Engi-
neer, petitioner, v. United States et al. On writs of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
Adjourned until Thursday, June 10, 1976, at 10 o'clock.

THURSDAY, JUNE 10, 1976
703
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
OPINIONS
No. 74-1303. Carl D. Bishop, petitioner, v. W. H. Wood, etc., et al.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice
Marshall concurs. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice White with whom
Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice Blackmun
join. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun with whom Mr.
Justice Brennan joins.
No. 74–1487. United States, petitioner, v. Colin F. MacCollom. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Ap-
peals for further proceedings in conformity with the judgment of
this Court. Mr. Justice Rehnquist announced the judgment of the
Court and delivered an opinion in which Mr. Chief Justice Burger,
Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Powell join. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Blackmun concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins. Dissent-
ing opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens with whom Mr. Justice Brennan,
Mr. Justice White, and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 75-93. Tennessee et al., petitioners v. Billy Don Dunlap. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-1075. Board of Education of the City of Elizabeth, New
Jersey, applicant, v. Brendan T. Byrne, Governor of New Jersey, et al.
Application for stay of judgment of Supreme Court of New Jersey
(No. A-96), presented to Mr. Justice Brennan and by him referred
to the Court, denied.
210-278-76-93

704
THURSDAY, JUNE 10, 1976
No. A-1079. Peter Webb et al., applicants, v. George E. Lohr, Dis-
trict Judge in and for Pitkin County, Colorado. Application for pre-
liminary injunction and/or stay of order entered by respondent on
June 2, 1976, in Criminal Action C-1590, presented to Mr. Justice
White and by him referred to the Court, denied.
Adjourned until Monday, June 14, 1976, at 10 o'clock.
