MONDAY, JUNE 14, 1976
705
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice.
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mrs. Jus-
tice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 75-1015. Ralston Purina Company et al., appellants, v. Louis-
ville and Nashville Railroad Company et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Western District of Kentucky. Judg-
ment reversed and case remanded to the United States District Court
for the Western District of Kentucky for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Mr. Jus-
tice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 75-1504. Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company,
petitioner, v. Benno P. Ludwig, etc. On petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Mr. Justice
Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 75-1561. Chula Vista Electric Company, appellant, v. State
Board of Equalization of the State of California. Appeal from the
Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate District. The appeal
is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon
the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari
denied.
No. 75-1580. T. Scott McVea et al., appellants, v. Board of Di-
rectors of the Federal Intermediate Credit Bank. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Louisiana. The appeal is dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a peti-
tion for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 75-1569. Arizona Public Service Company, appellant, v.
Arizona et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division
210-278-76- -94

706
MONDAY, JUNE 14, 1976
One. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. 28 U.S.C.
2101 (c)
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 74–116. Diane M. Place, petitioner, v. Caspar W. Weinberger
et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Petition for rehearing granted and
order of November 25, 1974, denying petition for writ of certiorari,
vacated. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in
light of Brown v. General Services Administration, 425 U.S.
slip op. 3, n. 4 (1976). Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of this case.
No. 74–851. Lynn Seeber, General Manager of the. Tennessee
Valley Authority. et al., petitioners, v. Alabama et al. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in
light of Hancock v. Train, 426 U.S. — (1976).

views of the United States.

MONDAY, JUNE 14, 1976
OPINIONS
723
No. 74-1023. Henry W. Kerr et al., petitioners, v. United States
District Court for the Northern District of California et al. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Mr.
Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of this
case.
No. 74–1254. Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers, International
Union, AFL-CIO, et al., petitioners, v. Mobil Oil Corporation, etc.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion.
of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Mr. Chief Justice
Burger concurs in the judgment. Concurring statement by Mr. Justice
Stevens. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell concurring in the judgment.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice
Rehnquist joins.
No. 74-1471. TSC Industries, Inc., et al., petitioners, v. Northway,
Inc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Mr. Justice
Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 75-5027. Russell Bryan, etc., petitioner, v. Itasca County,
Minnesota. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Minne-
sota. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of
Minnesota for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan.
No. 64, Original. State of New Hampshire, plaintiff, v. State of
Maine. On exceptions to the Report of the Special Master Maine's
exception to the rejection of the proposed consent decree sustained.
Proposed consent decree will be entered. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice White with whom Mr.
Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Stevens join.
No. 75-44. Robert Burrell et al., petitioners, v. Milton McCray
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fourth Circuit. Writ of certiorari dismissed as improvidently
granted. Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens. Dissenting statement by
Mr. Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with
whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins.
No. 36, Original. State of Texas, plaintiff, v. State of Louisiana.
On Exceptions to the Report of the Special Master. Exceptions of

724
MONDAY, JUNE 14, 1976
Louisiana and Texas overruled. Parties directed within 90 days to
submit proposed decree which has approval of Special Master. If
States cannot agree, Special Master requested, after appropriate hear-
ings, to prepare and submit a recommended decree. Opinion per
curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
Adjourned until Thursday, June 17, 1976, at 10 o'clock.

OPINIONS
No. 74-1529. Robert J. Henderson, Superintendent, Auburn Cor-
rectional Facility, petitioner v. Timothy G. Morgan. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
Judgement affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens. Concurring opin-
ion by Mr. Justice White with whom Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice.
Blackmum, and Mr. Justice Powell join. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Rehnquist with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger joins.
No. 75-5014. Jefferson Doyle, petitioner, v. Ohio; and
No. 75-5015. Richard Wood, petitioner, v. Ohio. On writs of
certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tuscarawas County. Judg-
ments of convictions reversed and cases remanded to the Court of
Appeals of Ohio. Tuscarawas County, for further proceedings not
inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Powell. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens with whom Mr.
Justice Blackmum and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 74–1267. Examining Board of Engineers, Architects and
Surveyors, etc., et al.. appellants, v. Maria C. Flores de Otero; Exam-
ining Board of Engineers, Architects and Surveyors, etc., et al., ap-
pellants. . Sergio Perez Nogueiro. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the District of Puerto Rico. Judgments affirmed.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmum. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Rehnquist. Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration or
decision of this case.
No. 74-1488. Thomas S. Kleppe, Secretary of the Interior, ap-
pellant, ». New Mexico et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the District of New Mexico. Judgment reversed and case

726
THURSDAY, JUNE 1, 1976
remanded to the United States District Court for the District of
New Mexico for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall.
No. 75-382. Federal Energy Administration et al., petitioners,
7. Algonquin Sng, Inc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judg-
ment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Marshall.
No. 74–1606. Hortonville Joint School District No. 1 et al., peti-
tioners, v. Hortonville Education Association et al. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the Supreme Court of Wisconsin. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Supreme Court of Wisconsin for further pro-
ceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart
with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 75–420. United States and Interstate Commerce Commission,
appellants, v. The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway Company et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Eastern District
of Virginia. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens
with whom Mr. Justice Stewart joins. Mr. Justice Powell took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 68, Original. Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, plaintiff, v.
State of New Jersey; and
No. 69, Original. State of Maine, Commonwealth of Massachusetts,
and State of Vermont. plaintiffs, v. State of New Hampshire. On mo-
tions for leave to file bills of complaint. Motions for leave to file
bills of complaint denied. Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief
Justice Burger. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmum. Mr.
Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice White dissent and would grant leave
to file both bills of complaint. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice
Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of these cases.
Adjourned until Monday, June 21, 1976, at 10 o'clock.

MONDAY, JUNE 21, 1976
727
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 75-1326. Lewis O. Vice, appellant, v. J. A. Ferguson et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Mississippi. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a properly presented federal question. Mr. Justice
Blackmun would dismiss the appeal for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 75–1476. The Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway Com-
pany et al., appellants, v. United States and Interstate Commerce
Commission. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Eastern District of Pennsylvania. Judgment affirmed.
No. 75-1550. William J. Vorbeck et al., appellants, v. Theodore D.
McNeal et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Eastern District of Missouri. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Brennan,
Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice Powell would note probable jur-
isdiction and set case for oral argument.
No. 75-1553. United States Power Squadrons et al., appellants v.
Marilyn C. Hinden et al. Appeal from the Superior Court of New
Jersey, Appellate Division. The appeal is dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a peti-
tion for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 75–1592. Keith B. Davis, appellant, v. Jan L. Davis. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Minnesota. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 75-1649. Henry Merritt Farnum, etc., appellant, v. Committee
on Character and Fitness, Supreme Court of the State of New York,
etc. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
210-278-76- –97

728
MONDAY, JUNE 21, 1976
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 74-1499. Jerry J. Enomoto, Director, California Department
of Corrections, et al., petitioners, v. United States District Court,
Northern District of California, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Petition
for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light of Kerr v..
United States District Court for the Northern District of California,
426 U.S. (1976).
No. 75-969. S. D. Cohn & Company et al., petitioners, v. Shirley
Woolf et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted, judgments vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further consideration in light of TSC Industries, Inc. v. Northway,
Inc., 426 U.S.—(1976).
No. 75-1481. Robert V. Stover, etc., et al., petitioners, v. Chicano
Police Officer's Association et al. On petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Petition:
for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light of Wash-
ington v. Davis, 426 U.S.-(1976).
CERTIFICATE SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 75-1728. C. Clyde Atkins et al., plaintiffs, v. United States. On
certificate from the United States Court of Claims. Certificate
from the United States Court of Claims dismissed. Mr. Justice Ste-
wart, Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Stevens would accept
certificate.

for the Ninth Circuit denied.

MONDAY, JUNE 21, 1976
OPINIONS
No. 74-730. John C. Roemer, III, et al., appellants, v. Board of
Public Works of Maryland et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the District of Maryland. Judgment affirmed. Mr.
Justice Blackmun announced the judgment of the Court and delivered
an opinion in which Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice Powell
join. Opinion by Mr. Justice White concurring in the judgment with
whom Mr. Justice Rehnquist joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Stewart. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens.
No. 75–292. The Serbian Eastern Orthodox Diocese for the United
States of America and Canada et al., petitioners, v. Dionisije Milivoje-
vich et al. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Illinois.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of
Illinois for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Concurring opinion by
Mr. Justice White. Mr. Chief Justice Burger concurs in the judgment.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist with whom Mr. Justice
Stevens joins.
No. 74-1563. City of Eastlake et al., petitioners, v. Forest City
Enterprises, Inc. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Ohio.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Ohio
for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Powell. Disssenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens with
whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins.
Adjourned until Thursday, June 24, 1976, at 10 o'clock.

THURSDAY, JUNE 24, 1976
743
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice.
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
OPINIONS
No. 75-491. United States, petitioner, v. Linda Agurs. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of
Columbia Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins.
No. 75-312. Coleman A. Young, Mayor of the City of Detroit,
et al., petitioners, v. American Mini Theatres. Inc., et al. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens, part III of which joined only by
Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Rehn-
quist. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell concurring in judgment and
portions of opinion. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with
whom Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice
Blackmun join. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun with
whom Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice
Marshall join.
No. 74-878. The National League of Cities et al., appellants, v.
W. J. Usery. Jr., Secretary of Labor; and
No. 74-879. California, appellant, v. W. J. Usery, Jr., Secretary
of Labor. Appeals from the United States District Court for the Dis-
trict of Columbia. Judgment reversed and cases remanded to the
United States District Court for the District of Columbia for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Black-
mun. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr.
Justice White and Mr. Justice Marshall join. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Stevens.
No. 74-6521. Monica Aldinger, petitioner, v. Merton L. Howard,
etc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals.
for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice

744
THURSDAY, JUNE 24, 1976
Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom
Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice Blackmun join.
No. 75-19. United States, petitioner, v. Dominga Santana and
William Alejandro. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice White. Concurring opinion by
Mr. Justice Stevens with whom Mr. Justice Stewart joins. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Brennan
joins.
No. 74–1607. Harry R. Hughes, etc., et al., appellants, v. Alexan-
dria Scrap Corporation. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the District of Maryland. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the United States District Court for the District of
Maryland for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Concurring opinion by
Mr. Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with
whom Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 75-510. Flint Ridge Development Company, petitioner, v. The
Scenic Rivers Association of Oklahoma et al.; and
No. 75-545. Carla A. Hills, etc., et al., petitioners, v. The Scenic
Rivers Association of Oklahoma et al. On writs of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment
reversed and cases remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Marshall. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of these cases.
No. 75-246. United States. petitioner, v. Alice R. Hopkins, etc. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Claims. Judgment
affirmed in part and vacated in part and that this cause be, and the
same is hereby, remanded to the United States Court of Claims for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissent-
ing statement by Mr. Justice Powell.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 28, 1976
747
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 74-1459. San Diego Building Contractors Association et al.,
appellants, v. City Council of the City of San Diego. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of California. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Jus-
tice White would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral
argument.
No. 75-111. Builders Association of Santa Clara-Santa Cruz coun-
ties, etc., appellant, v. Superior Court of California for the County of
Santa Clara (City of San Jose et al., real parties in interest). Appeal
from the Supreme Court of California. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Brennan would
note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
No. 75-466. Crestwood Education Association et al., appellants,
v. Board of Education of the School District of Crestwood. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Michigan. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Brennan would.
note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
No. 75-1712. Daniel M. Gaby, appellant, v. The Port Authority
of New York and New Jersey et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court
of New Jersey. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 75-6065. Rickey Mallory, appellant, v. Alabama. Appeal from
the Court of Criminal Appeals of Alabama. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied. Mr. Justice
Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall would note probable jurisdiction
and set case for oral argument.
210-278-76- -100

748
MONDAY, JUNE 28, 1976
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 75-169. Omaha Tribe of Indians et al., petitioners, v. William
A. Peters, etc., et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Petition for writ of
certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further consideration in light of Bryan v. Itasca
County, 426 U.S. — (1976).
-
No. 75-736, Environmental Protection Agency, petitioner, v.
Duquesne Light Company et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Petition
for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light of Union
Electric Company v. Environmental Protection Agency, 427 U.S.
(1976). Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this case.
-
No. 75–1116. H. L. Richardson, etc., et al., petitioners, v. Bob
Lokey. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted,
judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further consideration in light of Montanye v. Haymes, 427 U.S. —
(1976) and Meachum v. Fano, 427 U.S. — (1976).
-
No. 75-1418. City of Chicago et al., petitioners, v. Confederation
of Police et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Petition for writ of certio-
rari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to Court of Appeals
for further consideration in light of Montanye v. Haymes, 427 U.S. -
(1976); Meachum v. Fano, 427 U.S. (1976) and Bishop v. Wood,
426 U.S.
-
(1976).
-
-
No. 75-5958. Raymond Rickman, petitioner, v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light
of Doyle v. Ohio, 426 U.S. — (1976).
-

noted.

ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit from September 20, 1976, to Sep-
tember 22, 1976, and for such additional time as may be required to
complete unfinished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294(a) is
ordered entered on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C.
§ 295.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from today until further order of the
Court.

OPINIONS
No. 75–164. Pasadena City Board of Education et al., petitioners,
v. Nancy Anne Spangler et al. On writ of certiorari to the United

MONDAY, JUNE 28, 1976
755
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment vacated and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom
Mr. Justice Brennan joins. Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 75-251. Garland M. Fitzpatrick et al., petitioners, v. Frederick
Bitzer, etc., et al.; and
No. 75-283. Frederick Bitzer, etc., et al., petitioners, v. Donald
Matthews et al. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment in No. 75-251 reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Judgment in No. 75–283
affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Brennan concurring in judgment. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens
concurring in the judgment.
No. 75-552. Thomas S. Kleppe, Secretary of the Interior, et al.,
petitioners, v. Sierra Club et al.; and
No. 75-561. American Electric Power System et al., petitioners, v.
Sierra Club et al. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment reversed
and cases remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Powell. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall concurring in part and
disenting in part with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins.
No. 74-1520. Richard J. Elrod, etc., et al, petitioners, v. John
Burns et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed, Mr. Justice Brennan
announced the judgment of the Court and delivered an opinion in
which Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Marshall joined. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Stewart concurring the result with whom Mr. Justice
Blackmun joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with whom Mr. Chief Justice
Burger and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join. Mr. Justice Stevens took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No 74-1409. Lonnie North, appellant, v. C. B. Russell et al. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of Kentucky. Judgment affirmed. Opinion
by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Mr. Justice Brennan concurs in the re-
sult. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice
Marshall joins. Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration
or decision of this case.
Adjuorned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

WEDNESDAY, JUNE 30, 1976

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice
White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice
Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 75-1558. National Hockey League et al., petitioners, v. Metro-
politan Hockey Club, Inc., et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Petition for
writ of certiorari granted, judgment reversed and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Mr. Justice Brennan and
Mr. Justice White dissent. Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 75-1488. Robert Hampton et al., Commissioners of the United
States Civil Service Commission, appellants, v. Joan Myers. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the Southern District of
Ohio. Motion of appellee for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States
District Court for the Southern District of Ohio for further consid-
eration in light of Mathews v. Lucas, 427 U.S. (1976). Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr.
Justice Stevens would affirm judgment.
No. 75-6285. John H. Handfield, appellant v. New Hampshire.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of New Hampshire. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 75-404. Indiana, petitioner, v. W. J. Usery, Jr., Secretary of
Labor. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari

THURSDAY, JULY 1, 1976
763
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice
White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice
Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
OPINIONS
No. 74-1151. Planned Parenthood of Central Missouri et al., appel-
lants, v. John C. Danforth, Attorney General of the State of Missouri,
et al.; and
No. 74-1419. John C. Danforth, Attorney General of the State of
Missouri, appellant, v. Planned Parenthood of Central Missouri et al.
Appeals from the United States District Court for the Eastern Dis-
trict of Missouri. Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in part and
case remanded to the United States District Court for the Eastern
District of Missouri for further proceeding in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun in which
Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice Marshall and
Mr. Justice Powell join and in which Mr. Justice Stevens joins
except in Parts IV-D and IV-E, and in which Mr. Chief Justice
Burger, Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join except
in Parts IV-C, IV-D, IV-E, and IV-G. Concurring opinion by Mr.
Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Powell joins. Opinion by
Mr. Justice White concurring in the judgment in part and dissenting
in part with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice Rehn-
quist join. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens concurring in part and
dissenting in part.

et al., appellants, v. William Baird et al.; and

et al. Appeals from the United States District Court for the District
of Massachusetts. Judgment vacated and cases remanded to the United
States District Court for the District of Massachusetts for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Blackmun.

with directions to dismiss. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall in which

join; in all but Part IV of which Mr. Justice Powell joins, and in all

quist join. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Stewart concurring in part and dissenting in part with whom
Mr. Justice Rehnquist joins. Mr. Chief Justice Burger concurs in the
judgment. Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration or
decision of this case.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 11 o'clock.

CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 74-6593. Daniel Wilbur Gardner, petitioner v. Florida. Mo-
tion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Peti-
tion for a writ of certiorari to Supreme Court of Florida granted
limited to question 2 presented by the petition which reads as follows:
"II. Whether nondisclosure of a 'confidential' portion of a pre-
sentence investigation report to a defendant convicted of a capital
crime constitutes a denial of the effective assistance of counsel guar-
anteed by the Sixth and Fourteenth Amendments to the Constitution
of the United States, and of the right to a fair hearing as guaranteed
by the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment, in a case
where the trial judge declines to accept a jury recommendation of a
life sentence and instead imposes the death sentence partially on the
basis of the pre-sentence report?".

No. 74–5196. Jack Carlton House, petitioner, v. Georgia;

Mr. Justice Brennan, dissenting:
For the reasons stated in my dissenting opinion in Gregg v. Georgia,
428 U.S.
(1976), the imposition and carrying out
of the death penalty in each of these cases constitutes cruel and un-
usual punishment in violation of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amend-
ments. I would therefore grant certiorari in each of these cases and
vacate the judgment in each case insofar as it leaves undisturbed the
death sentence imposed.
Mr. Justice Marshall, dissenting:
Because I consider the death penalty to be a cruel and unusual pun-
ishment forbidden by the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments, see
Gregg v. Georgia, 428 U.S.
(1976) (Marshall, J.,
dissenting) I would grant certiorari in these cases and vacate the
judgments insofar as they leave undisturbed the sentences of death.
No. 74-6168. Clifford Hallman, petitioner, v. Florida;
No. 74-6377. Robert Austin Sullivan, petitioner, v. Florida;
No. 74-6563. Anthony Eugene Sawyer, petitioner, v. Florida; and
No. 75-5209. John A. Spenkelink, petitioner, v. Florida. Petitions
for writs of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida denied.
Mr. Justice Brennan, dissenting:
,
For the reasons stated in my dissenting opinion in Gregg v. Georgia,
428 U.S.
(1976), the imposition and carrying out of the
death penalty in each of these cases constitutes cruel and unusual pun-
ishment in violation of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments. I
would therefore grant certiorari in each of these cases and vacate
judgment in each case insofar as it leaves undisturbed the death sen-
tence imposed.
Mr. Justice Marshall, dissenting:

774
...
TUESDAY, JULY 6, 1976
Because I consider the death penalty to be a cruel and unusual pun-
ishment forbidden by the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments, see
Gregg v. Georgia, 428 U.S.
(1967) (Marshall, J., dissent-
ing), I would grant certiorari in these cases and vacate the judgments
insofar as they leave undisturbed the sentences of death.
,
No. 74-6717. Learie Leo Alford, petitioner, v. Florida. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida denied.
Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall, dissenting:
Petitioner contends that his right of confrontation, guaranteed by
the Sixth and Fourteenth Amendments, was violated because the
transcript of the preliminary hearing testimony of a material prose-
cution witness was read at his trial and the prosecution, although it
was aware that the witness would leave Florida prior to the trial,
failed to use available procedures to assure the witness' presence at
trial or to depose the witness before the trial began. See Barber v.
Page, 390 U.S. 719 (1968). On the record in this case, we would grant
certiorari and set the case for oral argument.
In any event, the imposition and carrying out the death penalty in
this case constitutes cruel and unusual punishment in violation of the
Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments. Gregg v. Georgia, 428 U.S.
(1976) (Brennan, J., dissenting) ; id., at (Marshall, J.,
dissenting). We would therefore grant certiorari and vacate the judg-
ment in this case insofar as it leaves undisturbed the death sentence
imposed.
-
No. 75–927. Patricia Hogge, Earle Phillips t/a Paradise Massage
Parlor et al., petitioners, v. C. E. Johnson, City Manager, and Pat-
rick G. Minetti, Chief of Police, City of Hampton, Virginia et al. Pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fourth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Brennan would grant the peti-
tion for ceriorari and, as in Colorado Springs Amusements, Ltd. v.
Rizzo, post, at -, remand the case to the Court of Appeals for de-
termination of petitioners' constitutional contentions giving appropri-
ate, but not necessarily conclusive, weight to our summary dispositions.
No. 75-999. Colorado Springs Amusements, Ltd., etc. et al., Peti-
tioners v. Frank L. Rizzo, Mayor of Philadelphia et al. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third
Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan.
No. 75-1238. Pennsylvania, petitioner, v. Aubran Wayne Martin.
Motion of respondent to leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania,
Western District, denied.
1
i

TUESDAY, JULY 6, 1976
775
No. 75-1482. Geisha House, Inc., petitioner, v. Maurice J. Cul-
linane et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the District of Colum-
bia Court of Appeals denied. Mr. Justice Brennan would grant cer-
tiorari and, as in Colorado Springs Amusements, Ltd., v. Rizzo, ante,
at, remand case to the District of Columbia Court of Appeals
for determination of petitioner's constitutional contentions giving ap-
propriate, but not necessarily conclusive, weight to our summary
dispositions.
No. 75-6112. Lawrence Edward Hart, petitioner, v. United States;
Jack M. Dixon et al., petitioners, v. United States. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Cir-
cuit denied. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Stewart would grant
certiorari.
No. 75-6596. Gary Eldon Alvord, petitioner, v. Florida. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida denied.
Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall, dissenting:
Petitioner contends that he was unconsitutionally convicted because
a statement he made during in-custody interrogation was admitted in
evidence during the prosecution's case-in-chief, despite the absence of
any warning to petitioner that if he could not afford an attorney one
would be appointed to represent him before questioning. See Miranda
v. Arizona, 384 U.S. 436 (1966). On the record in this case, we would
grant certiorari and set case for oral argument.
In any event, the imposition and carrying out of the death penalty
in this case constitutes cruel and unusual punishment in violation of
the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments. Gregg v. Georgia, 428
U.S.
(1976) (Brennan, J., dissenting); id., at (Mar-
shall, J., dissenting). We would therefore grant certiorari and vacate
judgment in this case insofar as it leaves undisturbed the death sen-
tence imposed.
ORDER
__
It is ordered by the Court that Alfred Wong be, and he is hereby
appointed Marshal of this Court, effective July 1, 1976.
-
OPINIONS
No. 75–122. Lawrence Cantor dba Selden Drugs Company, etc.,
petitioner, v. The Detroit Edison Company. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Stevens. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger concurring in
the judgment and in all except Parts II and IV of the Court's opinion.

776
TUESDAY, JULY 6, 1976
Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun concurring in the judgment. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Powell
and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 74-1055. W. T. Stone, Warden, petitioner, v. Lloyd Charles
Powell. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit; and
No. 74–1222. Charles L. Wolff, Jr., Warden, petitioner, v. David
L. Rice. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eighth Circuit. Judgments reversed and cases remanded to
the respective Courts of Appeals for further proceedings in conform-
ity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell.
Concurring opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting opin-
ion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Marshall con-
curs. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice White.
No. 74-1560. United States, petitioner, v. Amado Martinez-Fuerte
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit; and
No. 75-5387. Rodolfo Sifuentes, petitioner, v. United States. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit. Judgment in No. 75-5387 affirmed. Judgment in No. 71–1560
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with
whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins.
No. 74–958. United States et al., petitioners, v. Max Janis. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Cir-
cuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Marshall concurs. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Stewart. Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this case.
No. 75–339. Buffalo Forge Co., petitioner, v. United Steelworkers
of America, AFL-CIO. et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Stevens with whom Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Marshall and
Mr. Justice Powell join.
No. 75-76. South Dakota, petitioner, v. Donald Opperman. On writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of South Dakota. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of South Dakota for
further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court.

TUESDAY, JULY 6, 1976
777
Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Concurring opinion by Mr.
Justice Powell. Dissenting statement by Mr. Justice White. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and
Mr. Justice Stewart join.
The Chief Justice announced the following order of the Court:
"All cases submitted and all business before the Court at this term
in readiness for disposition having been disposed of,
"It is ordered by this Court that all cases on the docket be, and they
are hereby, continued to the next term."
Adjourned to the time and place appointed by law.
